name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on low-risk biological pesticides by Herbert Dorfmann, Pavel Poc, Julie Girling, Frédérique Ries, Lynn Boylan, Bart Staes, Eleonora Evi, Mireille D'Ornano, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000147/2016 - B8-1821 / 2016).

name: Pavel Poc
text: Author. - Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank all my colleagues, the co-authors of the resolution, for their excellent cooperation, all my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety for their support. This resolution was passed by a large majority in committee. I also thank the Commissioner for taking part in today's debate in person, and I believe that his presence will be of great benefit to our subject. The use of pesticides affects us all. This problem is a problem that is, today I would say, many eyes in the European public, and it is rightly so, because in 2014 alone, according to Eurostat, over 395 000 tonnes of active chemicals used in conventional fuels were sold in the European Union. plant protection products. Not the preparations themselves, but 395 thousand tons of active substances, this is necessary to realize. Of course, pesticides are, of course, primarily intended for controlling plant or animal pests. So it is not surprising that they are mostly toxic substances. What is worse, however, is that they are also carcinogenic in many cases and are often capable of damaging human health and human reproduction. Undesirable pesticide residues are found everywhere in Europe today. In water, in soil and consistently, of course, in our own food chain. And some groups of the population, especially pregnant women, children and adolescents, are exposed to this chemical cocktail and have very little resistance to it. No one - not even me - will argue with the thesis that European farmers must be competitive, but no one must - and I believe will not - argue with the thesis that this must not be at the expense of the health of the European population. It is therefore clear that the most dangerous substances need to be regulated and phased out, while offering agricultural tools alternative tools. The agricultural sector can and must be given a range of tools under the integrated pest management system, including low-risk plant protection products. But our progress in this area is unfortunately too slow. This debate and the proposed resolution therefore focus specifically on one type of low-risk pesticide, namely biological pesticides, which can be a functional alternative to conventional plant protection products and can contribute to achieving sustainable and efficient agriculture. Theoretically, these pesticides are already part of EU legislation and should be preferred by this legislation, but this is unfortunately only on paper. As far as I know, only seven active substances classified as low-risk are currently approved in the European Union, and six of them are biological active substances. The long pre-market approval and registration process creates a major economic barrier for manufacturers. We believe that there is a need to increase the availability of low-risk pesticides in the Union, and in particular products of biological origin. Of course, the resolution also calls on the Member States because, under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, active substances are authorized at Union level, but the authorization of plant protection products themselves containing these active substances already falls within the competence of the Member States, namely it is necessary to realize. And Member States should include the use of low-risk, low-risk biological pesticides in their national action plans for the protection of the environment and human health than they have done so far. The motion for a resolution calls for greater use to be made of the various instruments, including pesticides of biological origin, in accordance with the principles of integrated pest management. The resolution also emphasizes, of course, that consumer demand for safe food that is affordable and produced in a sustainable way must be met. Barriers to an accelerated procedure for the assessment, authorization and registration of low-risk pesticides of biological origin are known. We know that the situation should change as soon as possible, and the proposal therefore calls on the Commission to present it by the end of 2018 a specific legislative proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 beyond the review in the context of the REFIT initiative.I am aware, Commissioner, of your positive role in this area, and I would therefore like your answer to the following questions to be heard in this debate: What legislative and non-legislative measures are currently being discussed or adopted by the Commission to increase the availability of low pesticide biological pesticides?risk?What measures does the Commission intend to take in the future and what will be the possible timetable for these measures?Thank you in advance for your answer and I look forward to today's debate on low-risk biological pesticides.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to discuss with you today the topic of biological low-risk pesticides. Let me start by stating that biological pesticides are fundamental innovations that may provide our farmers with sustainable options to protect their crops and preserve biodiversity. For that reason, we in the Commission, like you in Parliament, all support this excellent objective. As you know, the Regulation for Placing Plant Protection Products on the Market requires a rigorous risk assessment of all plant protection products, and those of a biological nature are included in this assessment. Of course, assessing plant protection products means that biological substances are not automatically considered to be low risk. Indeed, micro-organisms and other natural substances can also be a danger to human health, so we need to look carefully at their properties and properly assess their risks in order to ascertain their safety. To obtain the strict status of a low-risk product, biological substances must meet additional specific low-risk criteria. The regulation provides for specific criteria and requirements for micro-organisms. It contains incentives to facilitate the placing on the market of low-risk products. The extent to which these incentives are sufficient will be assessed in the evaluation of the regulation, which, as you may know, we have started under the REFIT programme. The lack of availability of low-risk products depends on various stakeholders, from farmers to national authorities. Member States, in particular, have the responsibility of managing the sustainable use of pesticides and promoting greater use of low-risk pesticides and of all tools enabling the move towards greener agriculture. They should create better conditions for this to happen, and in particular they should launch awareness campaigns. As for the Commission, we share the view that it is important to take action to increase availability of low-risk products and to expand the toolbox for farmers with more sustainable options to protect their crops. To do this, we have assumed our own responsibility and we are currently working on three actions. The first is the funding of research and innovation in plant protection. Over the years, more than EUR 100 million has been invested in this area, and the Commission will continue to commit funding to the pursuit of sustainable solutions under the future research programme. The second concerns two regulatory acts. One is a Commission decision issued last September which prioritises the assessment of potentially low-risk substances for the renewal of their approval. When substances meet the criteria they will benefit from the relevant incentives in the regulation. The other is an amendment of the system for identifying low-risk substances. It will facilitate the identification of low-risk substances while fully safeguarding the high level of protection of health and the environment set in the EU regulation. I expect this amendment to be presented to the Member States for vote in March and then passed to the Council and Parliament for scrutiny. The third area of action concerns the follow-up to the implementation of current measures. In 2016 the Commission supported the initiative of the Netherlands Council Presidency to draft an implementation plan to identify key stakeholders with a view to increasing the availability of low-risk plant protection products. This plan was endorsed in the Council last June. It contains 40 actions for Member States, the Commission and stakeholders. Given that the authorisation of low-risk products is the responsibility of Member States, it is important that they play their part. The Commission is committed to working together with the Member States to implement the plan. Since the question which triggered this debate raises the issue of efficacy, let me highlight one of the actions identified in the implementation plan. The European and Mediterranean Plant Protection Organisation is working on a standard for assessing the efficacy of low-risk products. It aims to guide Member States on how to take account, in the efficacy evaluation, of specific benefits of low-risk products. The Commission encourages the creation of this standard and its implementation by Member States. To conclude, I am confident that the range of actions taken by the Commission will help to secure more sustainable alternatives for European farmers.

name: Norbert Lins
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I am allowed to speak on behalf of my colleague Herbert Dorfmann, who unfortunately cannot be here yet. Our aim is not to devalue conventional pesticides, but to support the availability of alternative pesticides of biological origin. Because plant protection products of biological origin with a low risk can represent a viable alternative for both conventional and ecological agriculture. The problem, however, is that there are lengthy approval and licensing procedures that must be followed before low risk pesticides of biological origin can be placed on the market. And this represents a considerable economic risk for the producers, who are often small and medium-sized companies and not chemical giants. The current approval procedures for plant protection products of biological origin with low risk are lengthy and take up to ten years. We are therefore calling for a specific legislative proposal to improve this situation within 2018.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I support all calls for reducing the regulatory burden associated with bringing safe plant protection products to market and thus widening the toolbox available to farmers. This includes alternatives to conventional pesticides, such as these low-risk pesticides. However, my concern with this resolution is the narrow scope, with the focus only on biological low-risk pesticides when the resolution should be looking at all low-risk pesticides, in line with the Plant Protection Products (PPP) legislation. I would also highlight the fact that there are genuine concerns about efficacy. Many biological low-risk pesticides are just not very effective and this is why they struggle to get authorisation. I do not support fast-tracking these products through a simplified authorisation procedure if they do not work. The point of a pesticide is to kill the pests, and if farmers use a pesticide believing it will work and it does not work, the fact is that, in the seasons it takes to realise that, the pest can take hold, as we have seen with cabbage stem flea beetle in the UK, particularly with oilseed rape. There we banned neonicotinoids: I am not arguing about that today, but the pest has taken hold to the extent that we are now not able to control it with other conventional pesticides.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, in the latest Eurobarometer survey on food, the presence of pesticide residues in fruit, vegetables and cereals appears to be the main concern of European citizens; the figures speak for themselves, with, for example, 95% mistrust in Greece, 85% in Italy and 72% in Belgium, to name just a few countries. We must of course respond to this growing concern in Europe about the use of chemical pesticides and the risks they pose to health and the environment. It is time, it is urgent even to offer a more varied choice to farmers, hobbyists or Sunday gardeners. That is, in essence, the message we are sending with our resolution on low risk pesticides, whether microbial, plant or animal. Nothing justifies, indeed - and this was said by Mr. Poc, in particular -, that only six biological active substances classified as low risk are approved in the European Union. For comparison, there are over 300 in the world right now - in the United States and Japan, basically. We insist in our text on several points to unblock this situation, concerning the legal framework in particular. Our request is clear: firstly, that the Commission present us with a legislative proposal to put in place an accelerated procedure for the approval of biopesticides before the end of 2018 and, therefore, to make a more varied offer available to farmers who choose sustainable; second - and for home gardeners this time, but it is important too - to make biopesticides the preferred option alongside other non-chemical methods. This possibility - this right to choose that I mentioned - obviously does not mean, in our eyes, more pesticides, on the contrary. Personally, I regret Indeed, to date, only Denmark and France - I conclude, Madam President - have embarked on a real reduction plan with a timetable and precise objectives.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (NL) Mr President, we all know that the use of conventional pesticides is increasingly controversial because of its effect on the environment, public health and fauna. Therefore, there is a need for a transition towards a greening of pesticide use; hence this debate today: promoting the use and development of low-risk biological pesticides. We have actually put six concrete demands on the table with colleagues and I would like to hear the Commissioner's reaction on this in a slightly more specific way. First, there is a need for an increase in the use of pesticides of biological origin. They must be available to a greater extent. Second, more research and development needs to be done, as they can be an alternative to conventional products. The Standing Committee for Plants, Animals, Food and Feed should actually accelerate the adoption of criteria for low-risk active substances. Third, the Commission, together with the Member States, should actually speed up the authorization, evaluation and registration of such low-risk plant protection products. Fourth, Member States should include the use of those low-risk biological pesticides in their action plans. That happens far too little. Fifth, the REFIT program that will review the Pesticide Regulation must not infringe food and public health safety. And finally, Commissioner, we ask you to come up with a bill before 2018 to speed up the authorization of these types of products. I hope you can agree with that.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too have signed up to this resolution to ask the Commission to intervene to facilitate the introduction on the market of pesticides of natural origin. In order to reduce the environmental and health impact of industrial products, including agricultural products, it is necessary to have the courage to facilitate in every way companies that believe in the green economy. Those who produce niche products and those who use them, it is not right that they face the same administrative and bureaucratic burden as those who do not pay for the passive externalities of their work. With molecules and pesticides of natural origin, it is possible to reduce the overall impact of treatments, thanks to reductions in emissions of pollutants and greenhouse gases during production and a reduced impact on biodiversity and non-target organisms and human health. A recent evaluation by the STOA of the pros and cons of organic farming found a positive impact of the consumption of organic products on some childhood cognitive disorders found at current levels of exposure to synthetic pesticides. So let's do it for future generations: agriculture can and must become the solution.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the ravages of Xylella fastidiosa in southern Europe - especially, recently, in Spain - are known. 2007 research demonstrating the effectiveness of enzymes in cow's milk illustrates the potential of biological substances in pest control. Paradoxical of a regulation intended to promote them, these low-risk substances nevertheless struggle to obtain the necessary authorizations. Thus, only seven of them, six of them organic, are authorized in the European Union. The paradox reaches its height when certain essential oils authorized for culinary use are refused this sesame. While the harmfulness of conventional plant protection products seems to be established and their effectiveness comes up against parasite resistance, there is an urgent need to support the search for solutions that respect the environment and health. This support is material, when it comes to start-ups, and regulatory, with a revision of Regulation 1107/2009.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, when we discuss free trade agreements in this House, everyone is proud to say that food safety, healthy and quality food is a great value for the European Union.If two hundred thousand tons of chemical pesticides are used every year, this quality, this health insurance, cannot be achieved.Yes, there is an alternative to low-risk biology pesticides.And that they are less effective than chemicals?Yes, but you have to decide: what is the primary goal?It is the profit of large farms who, of course, just want to use this material, or to support small, medium and family businesses that are just providing this healthy and quality food.A decision on this issue is obviously in favor of the European population.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Some time ago we were very controversial here in the plenary session about the plant protection product glyphosate, and I think we have worked out a good compromise. I hope that on the second attempt the Member States will be able to take a decision on this basis. Anyone who seriously deals with the topic knows that we have a dilemma here. We cannot completely rule out adverse effects on people and the environment, especially if plant protection products are not used properly. But on the other hand it is of course an illusion, especially in the short term, it is an illusion to convert all of Europe to organic farming. And that's why we need alternatives. We need research and development, we need approval procedures that are appropriate. I believe that there is still room for speeding up the process without questioning the effectiveness of these new alternatives. That is why, on behalf of the European People's Party, I support this resolution and ask the Commissioner and his team to work hard so that we can get these alternatives onto the market as quickly as possible - as alternatives for farmers, but also for the benefit of consumers. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

text: Blue card question.- Mr President, I agree that new and emerging technologies should be encouraged, and their introduction should be particularly encouraged.But why skip the part of how rural farmers with otherwise traditional education, aging farmers, will be able to get to know them?

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I see it a little differently.We should not underestimate the possibilities and innovative strength of farmers either.Farmers, even if they are a little older, are able to get used to and grapple with new technologies.I think we are doing something for agriculture, we are taking agriculture out of the corner if we not only have conventional pesticides but also alternatives.As colleague Lins said, this is an alternative to organic cultivation, but also to conventional cultivation.And I don't think farmers will have any problems with that.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D).
text: - Madam President, providing sufficient quality food for the global population, which is estimated to reach almost 10 billion by 2050, will be a significant challenge. Demand is already putting major pressure on limited natural resources, and competition for arable land is stimulating deforestation. Climate forecasts show that arable land will be threatened by other phenomena, such as changes in rainfall or the more pronounced impact of pests associated with higher temperatures. In this context, we urgently need solutions, we need more detailed research on low-risk pesticides and better procedures for approving them in order to place them on the market. Current procedures are too slow, forcing farmers to resort to conventional pesticides with all the implicit health and environmental risks. Alternative solutions, including organic plant protection products and other biological control methods, could also support organic farmers, but also low-impact agriculture in general. Many organic producers still have great difficulty accessing European funds due to still complicated procedures. The accessibility of low-risk pesticides would be an indirect support measure that would benefit them as well as consumers.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Any action to promote the implementation of low-risk biological pesticides is very much needed, even necessary, to reduce the risk of commonly used chemical pesticides and other ubiquitous xenoestrogens responsible for the epidemic of cancer, fertility disorders and even gender identity disorders. Only reducing agricultural chemicals and returning to biological agents - with the precautionary procedure and at the same time shorter implementation - can improve food quality and the health of consumers, all the more so as two-thirds of the world's production of antibiotics is administered to animals, leading to antibiotic resistance. All concerns of farmers about an increase in costs or a reduction in yields are unfounded, as shown by the experience of countries where pesticide use has been significantly reduced. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, an Ispra report documents an increase in pesticides in surface and deep waters in Italy. A Legambiente study entitled “Pesticides in the plate” certifies that one third of the fruit and vegetable samples analyzed have pesticide residues. Samples that have up to nine active substances present at the same time are increasing. In Italy alone, about 33% of the total quantities of insecticides used throughout the Community are distributed and there are 800 products currently on the market. The risks for human health, especially for children, are very high, let's think of endocrine disruptors. The damage caused to ecosystems, as in the case of glyphosate, the most widely used herbicide in the world, whose impact on the organism is insidious and slowly manifests itself over time, are extremely serious. However, as early as 2012, France recognized Parkinson's disease as an occupational disease caused by exposure to pesticides. The Commission must give us some answers, it must be accountable to the citizens for what it is doing to protect their health and that of the territory in which they live. We ask for specific action within two years and not a Refit procedure which could take up to 10 years and end without any decision. This would mean harming farmers and consumers who have the right to produce and consume products with the lowest possible risk. Today the real innovation, dear Commissioner, is adopting the agroecological approach, improving soil fertility, diversifying productions, increasing the capacity of carbon sequestration, guaranteeing adequate harvests and addressing the control of pests and herbs, monitoring natural dynamics. .

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we note that the number of active substances available on the market is steadily decreasing. We ask our farmers for more and more quality and less and less expensive products. To do this, we must invest in research and innovation and facilitate access to new molecules. We set goals, and it is our duty to empower our farmers to achieve them. Unfortunately, the current procedures are significant economic barriers for manufacturers. This is why we call on the Commission and the Member States to simplify approval procedures and to change good practices. But be careful: facilitating access to the market must not lead to reducing the risk analyzes carried out on these products. It is essential to guarantee the health and safety of consumers and users. I opposed an ad vitam aeternam authorization. "Organic" is not synonymous with "safe". After all, it was nature that produced the most violent poisons. Let’s stop opposing “synthetic” and “organic”. Based on sound scientific analysis, let's use the products that best meet our health, environmental and economic needs.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Madam President!Last year, when we had our big debate on glyphosate, both agriculture and many Member States complained that we in Parliament wanted to reduce the extension of the glyphosate license.They said it was because we simply lacked good alternatives to glyphosate.Today we are discussing what we can do to ensure that we get low-risk pesticides on the market faster and better.I think there is a great need for it and that is why we need to take a closer look at what are some barriers that make it so difficult to get them on the market.It does not matter if they are biological or non-biological low pesticide products.I think we need to take a closer look at where the barriers are and how we can speed up a process that allows us to get non-harmful or less harmful pesticides on the market faster.This is needed for agriculture, citizens' health and the environment.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I am delighted that there was such unanimity on this oral question in Committee and hopefully this will continue into the plenary, because across the political spectrum, there is agreement that we need to increase the availability of low-risk bio-pesticides without further delay. Access to these types of pesticides not only increases the toolbox available to farmers but they also help to decrease the residue levels of pesticides in the soil, water and non-agri-products.  By calling on the Commission to come forward with a legislative amendment allowing for the establishment of a fast-track evaluation, authorisation and registration process for low-risk biological pesticides, we are also helping to resolve other pressing issues that are facing EU Member States, issues concerning biodiversity and exposure to carcinogens.  Also, by increasing the options for farmers we can help to tackle food waste. Twenty per cent of fruit and vegetables lost in the EU is lost in the fields. Also potentially, by increasing the access to low-risk biological pesticides, we can help the fight against antimicrobial resistance. Recent studies have suggested links between exposure to herbicides and the effectiveness of antibiotics. So increasing the availability and promoting the innovation of more low-risk biological pesticides is a win-win for farmers, consumers and the environment.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - I regret that low-risk biological pesticides are still not widely available in the European Union.And we are well aware that the main hurdle is the long, slow and complicated certification process.It is also part of our fault - the European Commission, the European Parliament, because it is our will to change that.The slow procedure runs counter to the interests of all consumers, farmers and innovative industries in the European Union, and I do not see winners in this situation in the public interest.The REFIT procedure proposed by the Commission would take between 8 and 10 years, as already mentioned.And I see no point in doing that, linking the two together - the REFIT procedure can go its own way, and low-risk biological pesticides are being put on the market again in their own way.The European Parliament's Committee on the Environment has expressed its position very strongly, and I hope that Parliament will do the same on Wednesday.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, low-risk plant protection products of organic origin represent a valid alternative to conventional plant protection products, both for traditional and organic agriculture. The new mechanisms of action present in some of the new generation biological plant protection products could in fact represent an important advantage, also in light of the evolution of resistance to conventional plant protection products. However, a number of Member States refuse to authorize products containing low-risk active substances of biological origin due to their alleged lower efficacy. I am of the opinion that low-risk plant protection products of biological origin should be the preferred option for users where they are as effective as conventional pesticides. A revision of the regulation on the placing on the market of plant protection products is therefore necessary, aimed at improving the current process of registering low-risk basic substances which, in fact, sometimes takes the form of a kind of patent, making it difficult to '' use of a product having the same substance not registered.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, the use of conventional pesticides is increasingly being challenged because of the risks they pose to human health and the environment, especially when these products are not officially licensed or used in an insured manner. However, farmers must have a wide variety at their disposal in order to be able to protect their crops and decide what measures are available to protect their crops in the most sustainable way. Low-risk organic pesticides could be an alternative to the use of conventional pesticides and help achieve a sustainable agriculture. Therefore, in order to ensure human health and the protection of the environment, the availability of organic pesticides on the market compared to conventional plant protection products should be increased.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I am pleased that we are having this important debate on plant protection products and I hope that this House will vote in favor of the resolution on Wednesday. We have a problem: the food should be safe, cheap and sustainable, with the least possible use of space. At the same time, however, there are fewer and fewer pesticides available to farmers. We cannot leave farmers out in the rain here and we urgently need to ensure that a wide range of resources is actually available to them. Only in this way can agriculture meet all requirements. We are on the right track with the proposal for a simplified authorization for low-risk plant protection products. Still, I'm not entirely happy with the debate. There is a constant attempt to present biologically as good and synthetic as bad. Neither is true. The following applies in each case: The dose makes the poison, and responsible use determines food safety and sustainability. I would like to be less concerned with ideologies so that there is more room for the voices of practitioners and science. That is more effective.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: Madam President! Commissioner! This is a very important conversation about very low risk biological pesticides. It seems to me that these measures are a very good alternative to organic farming - which is particularly emphasized - but also to traditional farming. It is also emphasized here that the range of agents derived from traditional chemicals and used as pesticides is indeed decreasing as well. For a variety of reasons that have been mentioned here. The problem is the registration process of active substances of organic and non-organic origin, which is long-term, cost-intensive and also impossible to meet for companies outside the sector of traditional pesticide chemistry. The availability of biological and other low-risk substances for the production of pesticides requires support from both the European Commission and the Member States. And I think that citizens who are increasingly looking for food that is not protected with pesticides, active substances derived from chemical synthesis (due to antibiotic resistance, civilization diseases, even allergies) will also greatly support this direction of our actions and thinking.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened closely to this very interesting debate and I am grateful to this House for taking such an active interest in this important issue. I have taken careful note of your views and opinions, which will of course be given due consideration by the Commission.  Some of you asked why so few low—risk active substances have been approved up to now, but may I mention once again that this is because of the very strict regulatory framework. Regulation 1107/2009 allows the identification of a low—risk active substance only when the substance is going to be approved or its old approval under Directive 91/414 is renewed. This is the reason why only seven – of course, six of them are biological – low—risk substances have been identified and have been in force from January 2016. However, the majority of potential low—risk substances approved under Directive 91/414 have been prioritised for a renewal assessment, which will be carried out in the next three years. We will, of course, see how we can intensify such a process. Let me repeat that the Parliament and the Commission are united in supporting the broad aim of facilitating the wider use of biological low—risk, plant protection products, whilst ensuring that we maintain our high level of safety, because the European Union is very proud of the very strict regulatory environment and the very high food safety standards. Thank you once again for your valuable considerations and contributions.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 15 February 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: written. - Article 12 of Directive 2009/128 / EC on pesticides, establishes the priority use of low-risk phytosanitary products in areas used by the general public and in protected areas. Municipal gardens and peri-urban areas need to get rid of the pressure of chemical pesticides, which only add more pollutants to the environment where our children grow. For this reason, it is essential and urgent to develop a regulation available to low-risk plant protection farmers. The efforts of small innovative companies that have produced low risk pesticides of biological origin have failed in their attempt to access the European market. Currently only seven products with this rating are available in a market overwhelmingly geared towards synthetic chemicals. This resolution will allow a specific action within two years, instead of a procedure that could last about ten years and that could end without any decision taken. This would not benefit organic farmers or our inhabited environments, or consumers who have the right to consume food products with the least possible risk.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Bogdan Brunon Wenta and Norbert Neuser, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the revision of the European Consensus on Development (2016/2094 (INI)) (A8-0020 / 2017).

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank Norbert very much for his excellent cooperation on this report. Of course, I also thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive comments and cooperation. At the heart of our report was the reference to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, as well as a renewed commitment to eradicating poverty and fighting discrimination and inequality through the development policies of the Union and its Member States. An important point in the report is the internal and external policy coherence for development. It should be at the heart of the Union's strategy to achieve the SDGs. Action by Member States and those at Union level must complement and reinforce each other, and bear in mind the potential impact on developing countries. In this respect, an effective mechanism for monitoring and assessing this impact should be introduced. Official Development Assistance should remain the cornerstone of the Union's development policy. For this reason, the new consensus should also include a commitment to the Member States to achieve the 0.7% gross national income target by 2030. Good governance plays a special role in sustainable development, therefore the balance between the economic, social and social dimensions should be strengthened. environment by supporting national sustainable development strategies and good governance mechanisms and processes, including the participation of civil society. Development aid needs to be effective, and therefore ownership of personal development, transparency and the democratic inclusion of all stakeholders are essential. In the light of the immigration and refugee crisis, the essential role of development cooperation in combating the causes of forced migration and displacement should be emphasized. Politically stable countries are less vulnerable and prone to the situations that they may lead to massive and forced migration.Development assistance related to migration is important to stabilize the situation, maintain the functioning of states and provide decent conditions for displaced people.Regarding the link between development and security, it should be emphasized that development aid instruments can be used for the purposes of security policy, but only in relation to the goal of eradicating poverty and promoting sustainable development.The Union must promote the fair distribution of wealth by developing countries through national budgets, that is, both within and between countries.European development aid should distinguish between the situations of individual countries and their development needs.Microeconomic indicators or policy considerations should not serve as the sole basis for such differentiation.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Indeed, Bogdan Wenta and I worked very well together. That was also the basis for us to be able to come up with a good, compromised text. But I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs Charles Goerens, Maria and Lola, for many good initiatives and critical comments, because with their support we were also able to incorporate much of what the NGOs submitted to us into the consensus. Development policy is becoming more and more important; we in committee have always known that. But now - due to the refugee movements - this is also becoming a central issue. It is therefore good that we are now working on the consensus. It will be a manifesto. But it has to be more than just a manifesto. It must also include goals and implementation. As a committee, we want to know clearly how the objectives are being approached by the Commission in which timetable and how the Member States can be forced into funding. To do this, we need a clear commitment to monitoring and evaluating the implementation. We have a good presidency with Malta. Malta knows exactly how to get involved on the issue of refugees on the basis of the experience that the country has had. We work well with the Commission and with the Council. Perhaps we will manage to adopt our paper and our consensus at the end of June as part of the European Development Days. New - and that is why it is important that we have the consensus - are the global sustainability goals that have to be incorporated. It must also be clear that the fight against poverty continues to have priority in development policy, and the focus must be on human dignity. We have to try to provide answers to the new requirements: refugees, climate change and also the general set of values of the EU, which distinguishes us from other donors such as China or the USA. We should be proud of the fact that we conduct development cooperation in line with our catalog of values. We fear that a number of new financial instruments that require flexibility are not taking enough account of Parliament's rights. We have the impression that with greater flexibility our options as parliamentarians are restricted. I can only point out to the Council and the Commission: We in committee, we are also creative, we are also flexible. Do not be afraid of what we as parliamentarians bring in. We are close to the NGOs and we are also interested in our targeted contribution of good results. We have to see how the African Trust Fund and the European Fund for Sustainable Development in particular can be integrated and how we organize the measures to involve the private sector more and also to attract investment. That is why we, as parliamentarians, want to be part of the decision-making bodies. We want at least observer status. I would like to emphasize once again what I have already said: we have a lot of know-how and it would be good if this could also be used together. I believe that we as Parliament will adopt this paper tomorrow with a large majority. We did our homework. I think we can be satisfied overall. Let's wait and see what the results with the Commission and the Council look like.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to the Committee on Development and particularly the co-rapporteurs, Mr Norbert Neuser and Mr Bogdan Wenta, and the shadow rapporteur colleagues, who have put together this excellent report. Representatives from this Parliament and the European Union Member States are working together with the Commission services and the European External Action Services towards a new European Consensus on Development. This would represent a paradigm shift in development cooperation under the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and enable us all to better respond to the more complex and interconnected challenges the world faces today. This resolution, ably prepared by the Development Committee, is an important contribution to that discussion.  The European Union’s global leadership in development is nowadays needed more than ever, as underlined in the EU global strategy. The rest of the world expects ambition from us in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and its sustainable development goals: an Agenda based on openness, multilateralism and the objective of shared prosperity. An ambitious new European Consensus on Development would be a very important part of our wider implementation of the 2030 Agenda. It will also contribute to supporting the implementation of the landmark Paris Agreement on climate change.  I was glad to see this House calling the revision of the Consensus timely and necessary. The Commission presented its proposal for a new European Consensus in November, which provides the basis for the discussions ahead. A proposal for a shared vision and framework for action in development policy for the European Union and its Member States.  The Commission is looking forward to a successful conclusion of the discussions between the institutions within the first half of this year. This would allow for signature at our flagship event, the European Development Days in early June, and would provide the opportunity to present our new Consensus internationally at the United Nations High Level Political Forum for Sustainable Development in July.  Your resolution, like the Commission’s proposal, contains a strong affirmation on poverty eradication as the primary objective of EU development policy. This needs to come up clearly in the new Consensus. The resolution also recognises the challenges and opportunities posed by changes in the development landscape, including global trends, increased fragility and instability, and the 2030 Agenda. These would also need to be systematically addressed by our new Consensus. The resolution notes the changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty, which puts the objectives of development policy in the framework of the Union’s broader external action. In this context, among other things, the resolution highlights the necessity to find new ways of achieving development priorities in fragile and conflict-affected countries, including by linking up more closely with humanitarian actors.  Under the setup of the Lisbon Treaty, which aims at ensuring greater coherence of the Union’s policies and coordination with Member States, the principles of development effectiveness and policy coherence for development and the links with other policies, such as migration, security, energy, climate, gain ever greater importance. There is so much here that we can agree on. There are also issues which we will want to discuss in greater detail in the context of the upcoming tripartite discussions. I see this resolution as an excellent contribution to this joint endeavour and I wish to thank once again the Chair and the members of the Development Committee, and in particular the co-rapporteurs. I look forward to hearing your views in the debate today.

name: Maurice Ponga
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate our two co-rapporteurs, Mr Wenta and Mr Neuser, on the excellent work done. In this report, Parliament clearly expresses its political priorities for the future framework of our development cooperation. Thanks to the work carried out, the European Parliament will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council and the Commission so that the new European Consensus on Development contributes to the achievement of the sustainable development goals, the SDGs, adopted in New York in September 2015. J I had proposed many amendments which were included in the report and I am happy about that. I am thinking in particular of the need to strengthen coordination between our Member States in the context of the programming and implementation of our development aid. I also think of the importance of focusing our attention on global challenges, such as migration, security but also environmental issues, and in particular the issue of access to water management or the need to take into account the cultural dimension in our cooperation actions. We need to make our development aid more effective. This objective is crucial both for our partner countries and for our European countries.

name: Linda McAvan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I think the Commissioner has seen there is a big consensus in this Parliament on the importance of getting the new consensus on development. Commissioner, we will work with you and the Maltese to get an agreement in the timescale you spoke about. You also said that there are interconnected challenges. Your document is only one part of how the EU must address the SDGs. The internal aspect is very important, and that is why we place emphasis on policy coherence for development in our response to the proposal. I want to pick one issue here, and that is tax. We want to deliver on the whole Addis Agenda. Yes on the 0.7% aid. Yes on more private sector investment. Yes on making sure more tax revenue is collected. We know that DG DEVCO has a small unit on tax issues, but I wonder how much the wider tax issues of development are understood across the Commission, and how are you working across the whole Commission to get a proper tax policy that will deliver on the SDGs?

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the European consensus of 2005, which remains an essential reference in the field of development cooperation, is a collection of more or less precise principles and objectives, depending on the case. Let us also remember that the consensus is an interinstitutional agreement, approved by the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament, which aims to give development policy a solid basis allowing the European Union to build a common future with its partners in the South. . Respect for the principles of the rule of law, non-discrimination and policy coherence, which ensures that action in the field of development is not frustrated by interventions in other fields, is at the heart even from the report that our colleagues Neuser and Wenta presented. The problem is less to agree on commitments in this area than to ensure that they are kept, and this is precisely where the shoe pinches: what is the commitment to bring official development assistance to 0.7% of GDP if it is not held? Would it not be wise to provide, in addition to the funding objective, a political mechanism capable of ensuring that it is respected? Failure to provide for this mechanism is to perpetuate the Arlesian approach, which consists of always announcing the same event, knowing that it will never happen. Likewise, policy coherence will remain a dead letter until an arbitration mechanism is put in place to decide when two or more departments diverge in an important area. Finally - and I should have started there - do we all have the same idea of ​​what "the development policy of the European Union" means? From my point of view - and this is why I brought in an amendment - it is respect for human dignity through the eradication of poverty.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, do we want a cooperation policy that adapts to what is established by the United Nations Sustainable Development Agenda? So the European Consensus on Development must be based on three points. One, reinforcing the coherence of development policies, because these policies cannot remain a watertight compartment. We must be transversal, understand that all our policies have an effect on the global south, that is, we must be consistent. For example, our trade and investment policy must stop impoverishing and worrying only about the benefit of a few. We must bet on fair trade in line with human rights and with the benefit of all. Furthermore, we must develop binding human rights frameworks, that is, laws that ensure that everything that reaches European markets, for example, is not manufactured under exploitative conditions or stained with blood. As a second pillar, we must strengthen financing for development. And here we say that it is unacceptable that we have not yet reached the historic commitment of 0.7%. We must also support fair, progressive and redistributive tax systems in a universal way, and combat, once and for all, tax fraud. And finally, do not mislead the taxpayer, because official development aid has two objectives: one, the eradication of poverty, and two, the reduction of inequalities. Any other use, such as the control of migratory flows or outsourcing border control, is the misuse of public funds. And, in closing, I would like to thank colleagues Wenta and Neuser for their good work and dialogue in preparing this report.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. -  Mister President! First of all, many thanks to the co-reporters Bogdan Brunon Wenta and Norbert Neuser for the open and good cooperation. The European Union is in the process of completely realigning its policy, its development policy. And if the Commission and the Member States have their way, in future development policy should serve migration and security policy, because since the migration crisis only our interior ministers have decided on Europe's foreign policy. Funds will be taken from the poorest of the poor and should now be available for the military and for border controls. Parliament cannot simply stand by and with this report is sending a very clear signal. The goal of development policy must remain the reduction of poverty. There are other instruments and other budgets for borders, for security, for the military. If we shift more and more funds and keep adding new priorities, what will remain for long-term projects in the future, what will remain for education, how much for agriculture? I'm afraid: not much. The report by Norbert Neuser and Bogdan Wenta also makes it very clear that the principle of policy coherence for development must continue to apply, as stated in the Lisbon Treaty. And why do we as Parliament emphasize that when it is in the Lisbon Treaty? We emphasize it because the institutions, above all the EEAS under the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini, are undermining the concept of policy coherence and wanting to turn it around. But we will not agree to that. We as Greens can only agree if poverty reduction ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, first I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on this file for the good and cooperative work they have done. This is a report on a crucial subject at a crucial moment. The old consensus is about to expire and the European Union is facing a redefinition of its policies on development. This is happening while the European Union is addressing all the challenges caused by migration flows and while the European Union is under pressure. Development policy is about development. This might sound strange, but we have to repeat this concept, now more than ever. We have to repeat that development funds have to be used exclusively for development causes. We have to repeat that ODA cannot be used to finance security expenses, border control or military support. Of course terrorism must be fought in the most effective way, and of course borders have to be controlled, but not by diverting the funds devoted to development. Otherwise, poverty will never be eradicated, development will never be assured, and the root causes of migration and terrorism will never be tackled. It will be important to repeat this in the strongest and clearest manner during the structured dialogue involving Parliament, the Commission and the Council. This has already started and will bring us very soon to the approval of the new consensus on development.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- (NL) Mr President, in the past at primary school, in the sixth grade of primary school in Driebergen where I was, we had to take one guilder every Monday for development aid, for the Foster Parents Plan.Everyone did that well until it became known that the director of the Foster Parents Plan at the time was earning about four times the salary of the prime minister.Then the guilders of all those children no longer went into the collection tray, but were spent in the local sweet shop.And let that be an example.Because it is better to support the local middle class than crooks on the other side of the world.After all, development aid does not mean that money goes from rich Europeans to poor Africans.It is the other way round.Money goes from poor Europeans to rich African dictators and of course well-paid directors of NGOs.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: -  Mister President! If I look at the current UN figures in the area of ​​population development that is being planned for Africa, i.e. the African continent will at least double its population by 2050, if not multiply by two and a half, then I can see what some of my colleagues at Left tell us here, actually just wonder. Two and a half billion Africans should actually be able to count on us to support them in giving them the right to live in security and under reliable statehood. This not only has something to do with the fact that we want to protect ourselves from migratory pressure, but it has to do with the fact that we are trying to prevent the total explosion or implosion of the African continent by means of a coherent development policy. And that is exactly in our own best interest. Finally, I would add, because you will certainly not give me much more time: it might even be necessary for us to join forces with actors such as China in this context in order to divide up tasks. That would be better for Africa and, if necessary, for us too.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: You have correctly recognized that, my colleague: Nobody here gets any more time, regardless of sympathy or political agreement.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I thank Bogdan and Norbert for the magnificent job they have done in, together with the Commission and the Member States, to re-launch the fight against poverty at the heart of the global strategy of the European Union, inequality and the violation of human rights.Poverty has been reduced in many parts of the world, but it persists in many others.However, inequality is growing almost everywhere and human rights violations are multiplying, even at our borders or in countries like the United States.So that's our goal;fight for these three principles: against poverty, against inequality and for human rights.But, in addition, we have to put humanitarian action next to development policy.Increasingly, humanitarian crises are persistent, and the logic of development is needed to address humanitarian action crises.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all let me thank Mr Neuser and my fellow Members for their excellent work. Allow me to emphasize the inevitable important role of development cooperation in tackling today's most pressing problem, I emphasize, of forced migration. There is a need for a targeted development policy that can address the situation and needs of refugees' countries of origin locally. Let's have no illusions! As has already been said, programs to this end must be given a greater role in the European Union's development strategy, especially given that, by 2050, half of the world's population is projected to be African-born. Don't feed false illusions! We can only succeed if the European Union is able to carry out much larger and much more comprehensive programs under direct control, which is necessary, and without which we cannot stop the next wave of migration.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I also wanted to thank the co-rapporteurs. The review of the consensus, which will serve as a framework for European development policies in the years to come, could not come at a more suitable time, now that we must finally have a plan for the implementation and monitoring of the new development agenda at European level. sustainable. The real challenge is represented by the universality of the agenda. We therefore need coherent development policies, from the fight against inequalities to climate change, from the use of new resources for development to the commitment to reach 0.7%, to a relentless fight against tax evasion and avoidance that so much damage they cause to the poorest countries. If we fail to do so, we will continue to take away with one hand what we give with the other. We need to radically change our approach to the migratory phenomenon. It is not a problem to be solved, but an opportunity for development, avoiding externalization and the conditionality of aid. This is a short-sighted logic that would cost European credibility very dearly.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleagues Bogdan Wenta and Norbert Neuser for the excellent work accomplished on this dossier. I will focus on two points. Having drafted a report on development effectiveness not too long ago, I am pleased that the amendments I tabled on this issue have been included in the Wenta / Neuser report. It is very important that development effectiveness is one of the driving forces of our new development policy. We need clear references to this in the new consensus, including, in my view, in the section on principles. Second point, I am also pleased that the report recognizes the importance of policy coherence for development, PCD. PCD is a central element in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals. I believe that the European Union needs to clearly define the link between CPD and PSDC in order to promote this concept at the international level. PCD must become the hallmark of our external action.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I agree that our priority in development aid is the fight against poverty and the dignity of human life. Of course, we turn mainly to Africa, where the European Union invests the most of its development funds. There are 19 of the 21 countries with the greatest fertility, and at the same time there are not always stable governments in these countries, some of these governments do not respect human rights, and looking back at European Parliament resolutions, many of our resolutions on urgent issues deal with these African countries. So I say that we support the development of the economy, health care, education, which is essential in these countries, so that people do not have to leave their homes, but let us remind these governments that they have a responsibility to the citizens in their country. Unfortunately, this report also included a demand for the enforcement of sexual and reproductive health rights, as if other health care were less important.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would also like to thank my fellow rapporteurs on the objectives and the revision of the 2030 agenda. Our colleague Norbert spoke about some priorities: combating poverty and respecting human dignity. I welcome these provisions on a new global development framework on food security. European development policies can address multiple problems for humanity: poverty, unhealthy living, the demographic index. But it is not enough to have policies, it is important to be consistent. There are still large gaps between states and in many of them there is no money for medicines for the chronically ill, vaccine for children, conditions in hospitals. There are still remote areas without food, without water, without electricity, without access to education. Commissioner, what does the Commission intend to do to reduce these gaps? There is a lot of pressure from the economic giants on SMEs. You can answer, Commissioner, what can be done for a better life in the world and in Europe?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, growth in the world can only take place when there is a fair distribution of the wealth produced. Only in this way will poverty on the planet be reduced and only in this way will unemployment be reduced, since the world is now filled with millions of unemployed. Of course, there can be no growth as long as the over-indebtedness of developing countries exists. Therefore, the West, the G7 and China must move forward in writing off the debt of developing countries. At the same time, abandoning the policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment that the IMF often imposes on developing countries, combined with debt relief, will really stimulate growth in those countries and thus reduce illegal immigration. . We currently have huge migratory flows to Europe. We have huge migration flows to Greece and especially to the Aegean islands. Development, then, to reduce illegal immigration!

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - The European Union is not a union with a strong army that could intervene in conflicts.However, it is the continent that contributes the most to development aid around the world.It is therefore important that policy is coordinated to focus on key issues.And the issues of the coming decades are certainly related to poverty.With poverty in that part of the world where the highest population growth is also forecast, that is, Africa and also cities in general.That is why the problems of water, food and the environment will be the ones that will be crucial, and that is why it is right that policy is very much in line with these goals.Politics must also focus on creating new jobs, because with the new job we will restore dignity and eradicate poverty where we have the greatest sources of migration today.I myself advocate that the European Union continues to invest a lot of money in development aid, not in dealing with the consequences of the various conflicts and problems in these countries.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, we have dealt many times with the problems in Europe's neighborhood, problems that lead to crises, wars, the systematic production of refugees and illegal immigrants. But we have not dealt with the root of these problems because, as usual, we avoid looking at ourselves in the mirror and making self-criticism. The report on the European concept of development comes to fill permanent gaps in the Union's foreign policy. The allocation of funds for the development of third and developing countries is a form of curbing migratory flows. These funds are necessary for the empowerment of states, the building of stability, the creation of prospects, the fight against poverty and social inequalities. Combined with the control and accountability of the governments of these countries, it is a good start. Do not forget that the money of the European Emergency Trust Fund of the European External Investment Plan and of the Union budget in general comes from European taxpayers. I sincerely believe that development is, among other things, an inalienable human right.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, thank you, Commissioner!I would also like to thank my colleagues, Went and Neuser, for their hard work in preparing this report.However, I have two fundamental reservations about the resulting text.Firstly, the Malthusian perspective is not part of the European document.She is unscientific and has a touch of colonialism.EU development aid must focus on tackling the real causes of poverty - bad governance, lack of education and violence, and not on supporting population policy along the lines of the Chinese Communist Party.Secondly, we cannot ignore the fact that there is no consensus among EU Member States on the understanding of sexual and reproductive rights and services.Therefore, these issues cannot be part of the European Consensus on Development.Paragraph 23 does not fall within the text of this resolution and, if approved, I will not be able to support the resolution.Thank you very much.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to achieve the objectives set by the UN 2030 Agenda, the European institutions and the Member States have a duty to invest in projects that promote rapid and transversal change. From this point of view, sustainable agriculture must be recognized a leading role. Agricultural businesses help ensure food security, supply raw materials to local markets and ensure a fair income and decent living conditions for workers. That is, they constitute a perfect example of virtuous convergence between development and sustainability and a preferential path for achieving the sustainable development goals. It is necessary for the European Union to make this sector one of the pillars for its development policies, investing in the achievement of agricultural systems resilient to climate change, promoting ecological practices and improving the productivity of family businesses. Only with greater attention to the agricultural and food sector can the meeting between economic progress and quality of life be facilitated.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union was instrumental in shaping the global 2030 Agenda, which is fully consistent with Europe’s vision and has now become the world’s blueprint for global sustainable development. It is important that we fully take account of the Sustainable Development Goals in the European internal and external policy framework and current Commission priorities.  Development policy in the form of a new European consensus on development can make a central contribution in this direction. Therefore, the consensus is to be taken and defined together with our internal actions on a sustainable European future and our internal policies implementation, aimed at reaching sustainable development goals at home. This includes taxation policy where our actions against tax evasion, tax base erosion and illicit financial flows in the EU should guide and inspire our external actions on the collect-more-spend-better initiative within our partner countries. The Commission proposal provides the basis for the discussions ahead. At the same time, this resolution sends an important political message – that the European Parliament is actively engaged in shaping the future of the European Union’s development policy and is committed to eradicating poverty and achieving sustainable development by 2030 worldwide, ensuring that no one is left behind. The Commission is committed to working closely together with Parliament and with the Member States to ensure that the final consensus is exactly that – a true consensus owned by all EU institutions and all our Member States, able to spur action that can change lives across the world for the better.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their comments and remarks during this debate. I would like to add that the international situation has changed significantly since the adoption of the previous consensus. We have new challenges, of course, but also new opportunities and instruments. The revised framework for the Union's external cooperation in the form of the global strategy Agenda 2030 and other agreements, such as the Paris Agreement on Climate, the Addis Ababa Plan on Development Financing, and the Busan Accord on Development Aid Effectiveness, are an important impetus for this change. I am convinced that the adoption of the resolution will be a clear position for Parliament on the new consensus for development, which is to set the goals and policy directions of the European Union and the Member States until 2030. Parliament's resolution on the consensus will serve as a mandate for our negotiations and dialogue with the Maltese Presidency, representing the Council, the European Commission and the External Action Service, which is expected to produce a final text. As the priority goal of the Maltese Presidency is to conclude negotiations before the European Development Days, I hope that an agreement will be reached that will cover all the key elements of development policy, and a specific strategy for its implementation by the European Union and the Member States will also be identified. As colleague Norbert pointed out, there is little time until the European Development Days in June, but I think that time will not be an important element in these negotiations, but they must be effective, because this is to be the most important element, because the prepared text is to be a long years to come in development policy activities.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I think the debate has shown that we are on the right track here. The 2005 consensus had to be revised because many problems have arisen in the meantime: refugees and climate change. I want to make it clear once again that the question of financing development cooperation is very important. That was made clear again in the debate. We also want the evaluation here and an implementation by the Commission and by the Member States so that we can know when and how much money is being spent on development cooperation. We have the great advantage that the majority of Europeans fully support increased development cooperation. Eurostat says very clearly that the people of Europe want us to put more money into our hands to solve the misery and problems in the countries of Africa - especially in Sub-Saharan Africa. Another aspect was to what extent we might give funds from the development area to other areas. We are sticking to it: Combating poverty must have priority. For example, when it comes to securing borders in countries like Chad, Mali, Cameroon, Niger, Nigeria against extremist groups, against Boko Haram, I think nobody in parliament has anything against it. But we object if money is taken out of our pot. The Commission has to take more money into this. And one last thing about what the ENF representative said. I think it is outrageous to campaign here in the Netherlands on the backs of those suffering from hunger, disease and misery. That is something that should not be done in Parliament, and we must reject it very firmly.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday 14 February 2017.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Ian Duncan, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the cost-effectiveness of emission reduction measures and investments in carbon efficient technologies (A8-0003 / 2017).

name: Ian Duncan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me begin by thanking each of my shadows who have brought us to this particular point, to Mr Belet, to Ms Guteland, Mr Gerbrandy, Mr Eickhout, Ms Konečná and Ms Evi. I did not believe we would get here if I am being very frank. Just before Christmas, when we were contemplating this being a committee vote, I really did not think we had the vote at all. And yet, lo and behold, here we are. And coincidentally, it is my birthday. It is not for me to suggest that passing this would be a perfect birthday present. But I might just hint that that would be a useful thing for us to be doing tonight. It is important to stress again that is 197 days since I was given this particular dossier to move forward. Many of you here will remember I resigned as well during that process but you did not accept my resignation. So here I stand and again I am very appreciative of all who helped that be achieved. I should also again give thanks to the former chair of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Mr La Via, whose wise counsel at various points stopped me going slightly off the rails, which was very helpful. I should also of course, as I look toward the front of the room and I see in the form of Mr Cañete, a gentleman I once described as the Father Christmas of the College of Commissioners because again he brought back from Paris quite an extraordinary agreement. And let us keep to the fore of our minds during both this debate and the vote that follows that we have indeed got to stick with Paris. How do we ensure that we can stop the rise in the temperature of the globe? It is a simple as that. We often lose sight of it, and I have more than once lost sight of it, in various amendments, in various elements of this particular package. But what we are really focused upon, and I believe we must be focused upon, is making Paris a reality. I know that the Council conclusions are not there yet. I know the Council is not yet ready to embrace this; but they will because they have to. And I hope that the agreement that we secure by passing this report will help move it in that direction, will help remind those Member States they have a commitment which they have signed up to, that we must deliver against the Paris ambitions. It is also important for me to stress each of the elements of the package. I have been describing it to others a bit like a Jenga tower. I am not sure if Jenga exists in all the Member States of the EU but broadly, it is a tower of various blocks, and again the game is for you to pull out different blocks, hoping that the whole thing does not topple over. Well here we are folks. The question is which blocks are you going to try and pull out of the agreement right now and will the tower remain standing? I do not know the answer to that. That rests, I suspect, more in your hands than it does in mine. But what I do stress is as you pull out each block, just remember: if that tower topples, we have to rebuild it and we will rebuild it in a much less favourable climate, literally, and will also rebuild it in a much more challenging way. So please be under no illusion, when you are considering which amendments you wish to pull out or push in, that we need to deliver a package that works for everyone together. It is important, I suspect, for all of us here; each of us has particular constituencies and constituency issues, but nonetheless we must come together to deliver what is required for the climate and indeed for the European Union. Let me also stress that we must make sure that the agreement is Brexit proof. But I will say no more about that but leave that for the negotiations themselves. This is bigger than Brexit, it is bigger that the EU. Let us get it right. Final point again. I have been very blessed by an assistant system called Ross McKenzie, who helped me deliver this particular package. He is soon to be leaving my team, which I think is a bit of a shame. But nonetheless I am hoping through trilogue that we will continue to make progress. So let me conclude by saying: this is the time to get it right. We have got to pass this and I hope with all your support we can do that very thing.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, colleague Duncan.I speak for the whole house when I warmly congratulate you on your birthday.However, the Presidency cannot make promises about gifts in the form of motions for resolutions.

name: Fredrick Federley
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, I can reassure the House that the rapporteur for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Mr Duncan, has been so focused on this report that when I texted him at about seven o’clock this morning and said ‘Congratulations’, he replied ‘The report is not through the house yet.’ Then I said ‘Isn’t it your birthday?’ He had forgotten about that and was all focused on the Emissions Trading System (ETS).
