As rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy in respect of its opinion and shared competences on a few of the sections relating to the EU ETS, I must say that I am pleased by the team’s devotion to delivering a broad majority in committee, where the report was supported by more than 80% percent of the members, as one of the main tasks for us was to make sure we did not trigger the cross-sectoral correction factor and that we did deliver a strong voice for the forthcoming negotiations in the Environment Committee. We can see that we have done that. The vast majority of the proposals we had in the Industry Committee’s opinion were actually accepted and on board in the Environment Committee proposal, and we are grateful for that and also for the cooperation we had with the Environment Committee team. It is good that we made sure to keep the carrot in front of the industry. They were pushing for more innovation but, at the same time, it is a fragile proposal, as Ian Duncan was saying. If we start taking bits and pieces out of this, it will not add up in the end. We will not create stable conditions for industry, and we will not meet the climate targets. In my last few seconds I would like to call upon my colleagues to make sure that we deliver a broad majority for a strong proposal and do not take it apart during the vote on Wednesday.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, when Father Christmas scrutinises the behaviour of the children, you can be sure that Mr Duncan’s conduct this year will be taken very seriously because, Mr Duncan, you have done excellent work, unbelievable work, and I congratulate you and all the co-rapporteurs who have worked on this exercise because you have delivered a very ambitious report.  Also, as you said, we live in crucial times for climate policies, and following the historic achievement of the Paris Agreement, the European Union now needs to lead from the front. We need to deliver and put our commitments into a clear and binding framework.  The Commission has put several legal proposals on the table of the co-legislator, but the revision of the emissions trading system (ETS) was the first and has been debated the longest. The heads of state and government agreed in 2014 that the ETS is the European Union’s flagship climate policy and it is now time to show our citizens, our businesses, our society and the world that we are serious about making the ETS fit to meet our Paris commitments and our 2030 climate and energy targets.  We need to learn from experience and agree on a workable system that will do three things simultaneously: deliver the required emission reductions in a cost-efficient manner; protect vulnerable sectors in European Union industry; and support the clean energy transition where most needed.  This is the only way for the European Union to be credible when we are discussing with China, South Korea, Mexico and other G20 countries about carbon pricing and carbon markets. This is the only way to lead by example, showing how to drive emission reductions at the least cost to the economy, creating new opportunities for jobs and growth through innovation, and maintaining a competitive edge in Europe. Parliament has been working on this important file for more than a year and I am pleased to see the report is scheduled for a vote on Wednesday.  Forging agreement on the different aspects of the European Union ETS revision has been a very challenging task. I therefore again express my gratitude for the fine work undertaken by many of you present here this evening in Parliament. Multiple committees have been actively involved in the process. All views and angles have been discussed and weighed. The same topics are being discussed with Member States in Council. On some issues we can see signs of convergence between the co-legislators, which will be helpful in defining the final deal later on. The Council is also busy working towards establishing its position, enabling it to enter into interinstitutional negotiations. I am convinced that the political momentum is there to take decisions that will enable both co-legislators to start discussions. We need to bear in mind three key aspects which the revised ETS Directive must deliver and I welcome the fact that Parliament intends to send strong signals on all of these.  Firstly, we need to ensure that the ETS is fit to deliver the emission reductions to honour our Paris commitments, and Parliament is sending a clear message on the need to strengthen the European Union ETS via the doubling of the feeding rate of the market stability reserve. I see the importance of considering measures to strengthen the EU ETS which can ensure the carbon market functions and delivers the necessary emission reduction and innovation incentives. This is to restore the role we all want the ETS to play.  Secondly, we want to continue to build on our success in preserving the competitiveness of our industry and avoid the carbon-leakage risk and Parliament is enhancing in many ways the aspects of the Commission proposal catering for our businesses. We see the merit of the overarching objective of these amendments.  A notable aspect of this is the update of the benchmarks for free allocation. The report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety keeps the architecture of the Commission proposal with the flat rates and further enhances the role of verified data. It therefore rewards faster moving sectors by setting a maximum contribution and it ensures that the slower moving sectors also play their part by requiring a minimum contribution of 0.25%. Last but definitely not least, we want to increase the innovative power of the European Union ETS as a driver for investment in low-carbon technologies, and Parliament is discussing to send a clear signal on the need to boost the Innovation Fund for the benefit of European companies and to ensure that the Modernisation Fund spurs decarbonisation in lower-income Member States. When looking at these funds we need to be mindful of their effects on Member States auction revenues and favour elements that would bring the Council and Parliament together.  Thus Parliament is on track to set a constructive agenda for the interinstitutional negotiations. I encourage Members of the European Parliament to be constructive and to take the final step on Wednesday. This will give Parliament a united and a strong voice in the negotiations with the Council.

name: Florent Marcellesi
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mr President, the reform of the carbon market system leaves us with a bittersweet feeling. Agria, on the one hand, because from a point of view of the Development Commission it has not included very important points for us and us, such as, for example, the complete revision of the system in 2018 and, above all, an economic allocation specific to the International Climate Fund, because we know perfectly well that the countries of the South are the ones that have contributed the least to climate change and those that are suffering the most. On the other hand, also something sweeter - I only say "something" sweeter - because the reform that is proposed, at least proposes to abolish the free assignments of emission rights for cement, and clears the so-called list of "carbon leakage »By which companies can go outside Europe to continue polluting. Of course, it is not the dream agreement, but, as long as we do not accept the claims of the cement lobby, it is a first step in the right direction to comply with the Paris Agreement.

name: Ivo Belet
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to wish the rapporteur, Ian Duncan, a happy birthday and to congratulate him on accomplishing an extremely complicated effort with a combination of intelligence, flair and contagious Scottish humour. Thank you very much for that, Mr Duncan. This reform is key in terms of our commitment to the implementation of the Paris Agreement. It gives incentives to stakeholders from industry and the power sector, and it supports the best performers – those performers that strive for innovative and sustainable production techniques. But, at the same time, the new Emissions Trading System (ETS) and, in particular, the additions made during the vote by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, give guarantees to those sectors that are confronted with fierce international competition. Currently, a lot of attention is focused on the so-called carbon adjustment mechanism and, in particular, the fact that it will be targeted on particular sectors such as lime and cement. You will not be astonished if we say that we are not in favour of this particular proposal for several reasons. One reason is that it would be damaging for those cement and lime producers which export to countries outside the European Union. What is worse is that it would be implemented by means of a delegated act. For every true Member of this Parliament, I think that should be a no-go. Therefore we propose to support the proposal adopted by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, which is moderate and could be acceptable to all. Let us not forget that the cement sector continues to fall under the general system, meaning that the allowances will be attributed only to the 10% of best performers. So, as the Commissioner has said, the momentum is there to find a broad majority for a robust and balanced ETS. Let us choose the moderate option. Let us not jeopardise this proposal by focusing on one particular sector. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – You have mentioned some issues on which you disagree, and I have said that I agree with what you had expressed previously. However, do you not think that the Commission ought to be more ambitious and more in line with the goal of 1.5 degrees, set in Paris? This would be good for all of humanity, for all of mankind. As we speak now, there are islands that are disappearing – sinking. The water is going to cover them largely because of inaction.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – As I made clear at the beginning of my speech, this is about implementing the Paris Agreement – and not just the building sector, the transportation sector and the agricultural sector but also, of course, industry and the power sector have to implement what we agreed in Paris. Therefore, I must mention again that there is a lot of ambition in this proposal: what the Commission has proposed, the linear reduction factor of 2.2%, is much more ambitious than what we have now. And do not forget the Market Stability Reserve (MSR). I was a rapporteur on the MSR a few months ago, and the level of ambition now contained in this proposal is much higher than what we proposed a few months or a year ago, even if the MSR is not yet operational. Supporting that ambition is a very important aspect of this.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: for the S&D group. - Mr President! Thank you to the rapporteur Duncan for both your friendly way of leading the work and for all the humor you have shown and a big congratulations on your birthday. I hope that other groups will also listen to your important calls before the vote to keep this compromise together. On Wednesday, Europe will declare color. We have a historic opportunity to show that we are serious about our work against climate change and global warming. We have the chance to show now that Europe is serious, that we want to take the lead in a sustainable climate-smart society, built with new world-class fossil-free and smart technologies, that we understand that good climate work and economic growth are not opposites, but on the contrary belong together and are interdependent. Emissions trading ETS is the EU's single most important climate policy tool for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. ETS is absolutely central to our success. This means that ETS now plays a key role, not only for Europe but also for the world and for how we will live up to the Paris Agreement's ambitions to limit the temperature increase to well below two degrees. ETS is not a perfect system. None of us say that. Over the years, we have seen a number of errors and shortcomings in this system that need to be addressed, but that is what we are working on now, for a strong system that delivers. For us Social Democrats, there have been three principles that have been guiding: 1) to ensure that the ETS is really in line with the Paris Agreement and delivers for the climate, 2) that it is more fair and precise for the industry, so we get rid of the imbalances we have seen in the historical ETS and 3) that we also ensure that workers have the chance to be part of the transition to a climate-smarter society, so that it is fair. For us Social Democrats, the ETS is the single most important part of delivering after Paris. To do that, we must burst the emission bubble and then emission rights must be reduced by at least 2.4 percent each year. 2) At the same time, it is important for us that the industry is given the right tools to switch to climate-smart production without losing competitiveness, but on the contrary is strengthened. That is why we give more money to innovation so that companies can invest in greener solutions. 3) It is also important that climate change is solidary and does not increase class divisions. It must not be the case that those who already have the least are the ones who fall behind when society is modernized and becomes climate-smarter. That is why we Social Democrats demand a special social adjustment fund that provides support so that workers in all sectors and regions covered can follow this important adjustment in society. The vote on Wednesday is a baptism of fire for the EU's climate work. It is now that the EU must show that it is willing to act not only with nice words, but also with concrete measures to keep the Paris goals. For us Social Democrats, this is a matter of course and before the vote on Wednesday, there is an agreement that all political groups have signed. It is a compromise where everyone can give and take, but as a negotiator for the Social Democratic group, I know how sensitive such a compromise is. We take responsibility now and stand up for the compromise and think it is important on Wednesday. We stand up for the climate and ensure that the ETS becomes the climate legislation it should be and this is so important so now I got my last word ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in the ECR we are firm proponents of market-based mechanisms and there are many positive elements in the agreement reached by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. I do not accept the analysis that you have to agree with them all at this stage in plenary, because there are a few things that are not so good. One in particular for us is the issue of Member States having final say over the use of their receipts from this scheme. In order to ensure their continued commitment, we would be rejecting the issues of fiscal sovereignty.  I firmly believe that any legislation should be based on robust evidence. Parliament should not simply add new components that have not been impact-assessed. If we are serious about reducing greenhouse gases, then the policy framework must be evidence-based and encourage industry to invest in low-carbon technology. Moving the goalposts or, at worst, scoring an own goal, will not do any good in lowering emissions in the long run.  We are particularly concerned about the late inclusion of a border-adjustment mechanism, added days before the vote in the Environment Committee, with no study on its impacts or costs. For the ECR, this is not the way to protect against carbon leakage. Indeed, the provision of free allocations for those sectors most at risk is the best way forward.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, ‘it is not always enough that we do our best; sometimes we have to do what is required’. With these words attributed to Winston Churchill, Secretary of State John Kerry made a very impressive speech in Marrakesh during the COP 22 last year. He made absolutely clear that we have to do what is required instead of just doing our best.  Those words went through my head many times during our negotiations. Are we doing our best or are we doing what is required? I am afraid we have not done that. Yes, we did improve the original Commission proposal here and there. We increased the ambition with a higher linear reduction factor. We do intend to cancel 800 million allowances and we found a way to limit the amount of free allowances given to industrial sectors with low trade intensity without endangering their competitiveness internationally.  But we have to be honest; we also watered-down parts of the original proposal. We lowered the annual benchmark, we lowered the threshold for qualitative assessment and we opened a door to lower the auction share.  The package that came out of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, for me, is far from ideal, but it is the best that we could get out of it. Does it pass the Churchill test? Is it doing what is required? I doubt it.  Let us make clear what is in the Paris Agreement: two degrees and even if possible stay close to the one point five degrees. Two degrees means that we have only 20 years left of current global emissions. One point five degrees, we have less than five years left. That is close to nothing. To those who simply and only want to do their best, please vote Wednesday in favour of the total Environment Committee package without any amendments. Stick to it and you are not doing what is required; you are only doing your best.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all let me thank not only the rapporteur, Mr Duncan, but above all all my colleagues, because although the negotiations were very long, sometimes quite quiet, I think they were very concrete and factual in the end, and we have shown that we can work together. when it comes to a good thing. However, we are now at a critical moment. I will not discuss here all the positives or negatives that the submitted document has. We all knew after the vote in the ENVI Committee that the text adopted would probably not fully satisfy any camp. On the one hand, we have a number of great measures that will lead to an increase in the price of allowances and a reduction in CO2 emissions, such as new LRF, higher runoff to MSR, deletion of 800 million allowances, etc. On the other hand, correction factor for the sectors most at risk of carbon leakage. Looking at the amendments tabled, it occurs to me that it is possible to talk about trifles, but in the rest I would call for moderation. Each side had to back away. But I am afraid that we are not able to rework this balanced agreement from the ENVI Committee in plenary in any way now and here. Politics is simply the art of the possible. And a strong mandate in the Council will only give us a strong mandate from the plenary. As a birthday present, I would like my colleague to get that strong and solid tower without anyone taking any dice out of it.

name: President. –
text: We have noticed up here that you cannot see the time while you are speaking. The technical services are trying to change this. After two-and-a-half minutes, I will just hammer and you will hear that.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to refer back to December 2015 when everyone in this room was applauding the Paris Agreement. As a Green, I was happy to see how from the left to the right of Parliament they were embracing Paris. Well, we are now discussing the only climate tool we have for European industry. That is what we are discussing here, so this is now the moment when all those nice words on Paris should be translated into action.  Let us see what those words were worth, because we know that the current system is not functioning well enough and that is why, for example, one of the crucial elements is raising the linear reduction factor, which brings us a bit closer to Paris, just a bit. We are now at the low end of the two degree scenario. So that is what we are doing.  Anyhow, in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety they managed to strike a deal spanning the political groups, from GUE to ECR – a broad agreement in the Environment Committee – and they all said yes to this package, and yes, it has higher ambition, which makes it good for us, but it also has a lot of additional protection for industry. It protects, in addition, the fertiliser and the steel sector. It has a higher innovation fund. It gives new benchmarks. It provides a compensation fund for indirect costs; all kinds of things added. This has all been put together now, and yet this package is being attacked again. Why? Because of one sector which is complaining.  Maybe, first, everyone should realise that the rule is auctioning. When we single out sectors we do that by making them free allowances. That is singling out. We want to do that for those sectors which have international competition. Looking at the cement sector, they have increased their exports because of the free allowances. They halted their innovation because they are dependent on those free allowances and therefore keep to high carbon cement, and they earned windfall profits of EUR five billion in the last phase.  That is what cement did with innovation, and that is what we are now going to address. We will put them back where they belong, outside free allocation. But we are giving them an alternative and that is the border adjustment measure. We are giving an alternative. We do not leave them on their own. That is exactly what we are doing. It is a balanced package and this will help us not to trigger the cross-sectoral correction factor, because now the real sectors deserving free allowances will get them, and that is what we should do.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in these months of working on the ETS file we have devoted a great deal of time to investigating the problems facing industries: commercial codes, the complex calculation operations for the allocation of free quotas, the various funds compensation and innovation. But there has been very little debate on the real effectiveness of the ETS in reducing emissions. No one has explained to us, for example, how we can be sure that by applying a percentage reduction, the so-called linear reduction factor, i.e. the gradual reduction of the emission quotas assigned to the plants, a real reduction in emissions is achieved. I repeat a real reduction and not a virtual one. In fact, given that real emissions are known only the year after they occur, the only certainty that can be had is that plants that emit more than they are allowed will simply have to purchase additional emission permits to those previously received. Here is the most absurd, insane and distorted application of the "polluter pays" principle. But let's console ourselves since at least the ETS produces money by selling the shares. But whoever hopes that this money will be used to finance measures to compensate for emissions that are already in the atmosphere, are mistaken, it is just an illusion, there is no obligation for Member States on this. Not to mention the trading of securities on the financial market, which will continue to represent a mere profit for speculators. But there is more: we asked the industry what CO2 price was convenient, according to them, to invest in structural improvements to apply the best technologies, considering a CO2 price subject to fluctuations. Everyone, without exception, admitted that they are unable to make these assessments and that they have no incentive to make major investments in the absence of stability.But wasn't the ETS supposed to incentivize low-carbon innovation?In short, the system does not work.From our point of view, the more ambitious and binding targets on renewables, efficiency and energy savings could bring much more concrete and immediate results.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, we reject the reform relating to greenhouse gas emission quotas, both for legal reasons and in principle. We do not accept the strengthening of the prerogatives of the Commission nor the inclusion of the international maritime and air sectors in disregard of the competences of the International Maritime Organization and the International Civil Aviation Organization. In principle, these new constraints linked to emissions will stimulate frenzied competition from low-cost states, often unscrupulous in environmental matters. With overcapacity of 350 million tonnes, Chinese steel is already flooding the European Union market, which has been a net importer since 2015. France having already lost 900,000 industrial jobs in fifteen years, we do not wish to join this process. reform which threatens to spell the end of our industry, as well as of 437 blast furnaces in the European steel sector.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to wish Mr Duncan a happy birthday. Mr Duncan, I am sorry that I cannot offer you a birthday present in terms of supporting what you have done, but I am grateful for the effort you have put in. Let us just remind ourselves about the European Union’s Emissions Trading System and what it has brought about. Recognised as being one of the most flawed policy initiatives in history, since 2005 it has been a shameful litany of mismanagement, hidden subsidies, lobby power, environmental degradation, job losses, theft and fraud. One of my colleagues made a very important point: where is the risk analysis in all of this? Just think about the impact that this is going to have if it goes through – and I do not doubt it will. Creating an impetus for unemployment and exporting pollution are hardly two aspects that this organisation, the European Union, ought to be proud of. Neither is the inclusion in the system of, for instance, aviation and shipping – two pivotal elements in making food imports possible. I am sorry, everyone: I will not be able to support this.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Thank you very much, Mr President. Thank you, congratulations also to the rapporteur, Ian Duncan, who is not listening but who chose a very unfortunate example of the Jenga tower. Mr Duncan, as it happens to be, I am my family’s... (Interruption from the floor: ‘Ian, Ian’) First of all, I congratulated you to your birthday, despite your very unfortunate example of the Jenga tower because, as it happens, I am my family’s Jenga champion, so I am available for a match at any time. I am confident, however, that on this issue I will not need too much of my Jenga skills because I do think that, with Frederick Federley’s opinion in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, we had a very good opinion which then served as a basis of the report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. I have a whole list in front of me, of the elements of Frederick’s opinion that were then carried over to the Environment Committee report. I will mention just one of them, which is the free allowances – the 5% additional free allowances that are really, and should be, a key point to the entire Parliament. Hopefully we get broad support for that tomorrow, knowing that it is not very popular in Council. On the border adjustment mechanism, it was never a secret and therefore cannot have come as a surprise that the EPP Group would prefer the broader and the fairer wording of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. You are looking at me very sternly Mr President but I had to start over again because the rapporteur was not paying attention. Let me just still say two more things. (Interjection from the President: ‘No, no, the rapporteur not listening does not change the Rules of Procedure’) I was being nice to a colleague. Since we started working on this issue, the world has changed. We now have someone in America who could easily walk the road of climate scepticism. That means that we in Europe should choose leadership but that we also should not be naive. The others are playing hardball and therefore we should be prepared.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: - Mr President, during this debate, the Socialist Group was the only one to defend the alliance of three ambitions: climate, industrial and social. A climate ambition, first. Contrary to what the Commission boasts, the Emissions Trading System (ETS) has so far failed to decarbonize our economy at a lower cost. The variations in greenhouse gas emissions came mainly from the economic crisis and from national energy transition choices independent of the ETS. Moreover, everyone agrees that the current price per tonne of CO2 is very insufficient to encourage low-carbon investments in manufacturers and electricians. This strongly depressed price responds to the gigantic surplus of allowances in the system - between two and three billion tonnes. This is why it is important, in the name of consistency with the commitments we made in Paris, to tighten the tap more strongly by voting a linear reduction factor of 2.4% and removing a quota of 800 million euros. tonnes of surplus allowances. An industrial ambition, too. I come from the working-class world, I know the quality of our industries and the competence of our workers, but it is wrong to claim that it is by the simple extension of the status quo, that is to say by widely distributing quotas free, that we will relaunch investments. Indeed, what did the manufacturers do with the millions of free allowances often distributed in excess? Very often - too often - the proceeds from the sale of these quotas received went directly into the pockets of shareholders. We must therefore put an end to these abuses. This is the whole purpose of the proposed changes, such as the distribution of quotas on a more dynamic basis, the revision of benchmarks, a more ambitious investment fund or, quite simply, the mandatory orientation of surpluses. towards investment.But I think it's time to move on to an alternative method of protecting against carbon fluxes.The carbon adjustment at borders for certain sectors such as cement will be decisive.Our ambition is also to support the modernization of electricity producers.It is perfectly legitimate for the European Union, in a solidarity approach, to finance a specific component for economically less advantaged countries, but it is just as legitimate for these sums to be invested in energy projects in accordance with our common roadmap..The new criteria proposed will allow all the beneficiary countries to modernize their fleet, even Poland, which is indeed starting from far away to gradually phase out coal.I will conclude, Madam President, by also mentioning the just transition fund for workers.

text: I understood that there was a problem with the posting of speaking times.I will try to build on what my colleague Lambsdorff has done, which is to say that you are at the end of your speech.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, in order to significantly reduce CO2 emissions, we need an emissions trading system that is efficient, balanced and innovative. If we want to put the Paris Agreement into practice, the functioning of the carbon market must be better and more efficient. For example, we must stimulate a more robust price for CO2 climate-friendly investments and we must create an important balance in this respect. The reform must protect the climate and jobs and that is essential. We must not turn winners into losers. When companies move from Europe to third countries where climate rules are less strict, we lose twice: the jobs are gone and we are doing nothing for the climate. The strong focus on innovation is also crucial. A low-carbon Europe is not only achieved through a workable system of emission rights, but also requires innovative solutions. Our policy choices must be sustainable, efficient and effective so that they can last for decades. We want to ride in the peloton with Flanders and Europe without getting a flat tire. This reform is a step in the right direction and has my support.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE / NGL). - Colleagues, I would like to point out three critical problems caused by the proposals for exclusion from the list of carbon leakage hazards and the introduction of a pipeline compensation mechanism with unspecified practical application possibilities. First, the exclusion of the cement sector from the list will make many Member States' exports uncompetitive vis-εκτός-vis countries outside the system. In particular, the Greek cement industry, with 13,000 employees and a trade intensity of 45%, ie more than multiples of the 10% limit, will lead to withering and disappearance. Secondly, the eligibility of new projects to be financed by the newly established Modernization Fund must be based on 2015 or at most 2014 in order to reflect the current economic reality in the Member States. Thirdly, with regard to the integration of shipping into the emissions trading scheme, any regulation at regional level is likely to have an adverse effect on the industry at European level. Our goal should be the timely establishment of a similar system at the level of the International Maritime Organization. We have tabled amendments to the above and I would ask for the special attention of colleagues and their vote.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! The present report provides for the energy-intensive stone and ceramic industries to be removed from the carbon leakage list and for border adjustment measures to be introduced. Changes are necessary here and I would like to give you an example of why these changes are necessary. The purchase of emission certificates alone costs the Austrian cement industry EUR 80 million a year. That is a cost increase of 20% of the total turnover in the industry, even though, according to the World Business Council for Sustainable Development, the Austrian cement industry has the lowest CO2 emissions and by far the highest level of utilization of alternative fuels and is the leader in innovative technologies for reducing emissions. It can be doubted that immature and untested border adjustment measures offer sufficient protection and compensation against imports from third countries. It is also questionable whether this measure is WTO-compatible at all. And one thing is clear: The competitiveness of cement, lime, brick and glass products compared to building and basic materials is falling, and the price of the products is rising. Carbon leakage is therefore also investment leakage. And that costs jobs and growth and means a weakening of the competitiveness of European companies.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. If the ETS works properly, it is a powerful tool for triggering investments in climate-friendly technologies. With this we help the climate and jobs. That is why we have to strengthen the ETS, the prices have to rise. But we also have to make it clear that the top 10% of the companies that have invested are safe and not burdened by the ETS. In principle, the report does both. But we have a big exception with cement and some other products, and that gives us stomach ache. We therefore urgently want a change at this point. The mechanisms that have been proposed, and which some colleagues now support, are shaky. We do not know whether we can enforce it. At the same time, we also do not know whether such a tightly tailored border tax adjustment only for cement, on the basis of a delegated legal act, is not going to fall short. If we do that, then maybe we should reserve it in case other nations, like the United States, pull out of climate protection completely. But it is at least not fully developed, and that is why I urge colleagues to support Amendment 144. In the industry committee, the latter also found support from social democrats and liberals. So he seems quite reasonable after all. If we have approval tomorrow, there will be a large majority in favor of the report and then we can all be satisfied.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: - Madam President! First of all, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Ian Duncan, for his commitment. Happy birthday, Ian. I would also like to thank the ITRE rapporteur, Mr Federley, for his commitment. The Council must absolutely prevent the industry from being forced to save a flat rate of 2.4% a year instead of 2.2% - as proposed by the Commission. We have just heard it again, it is always the same MPs who complain here about deindustrialization and then drive industry to other regions with environmental regulations. It is always the same MEPs who complain about unemployment in Europe and then make their contribution to the disappearance of jobs about energy costs being too high. But not only that, ladies and gentlemen. It is often the same colleagues who loudly advocate lower CO2 emissions in the EU and then quietly increase global CO2 emissions. In view of the globalization of the economy on the one hand, we cannot ignore the global nature of the climate problem on the other. Cement, aluminum, ceramics, steel and chemical products are already being produced in Europe under significantly more environmentally friendly conditions than anywhere else in the world. If we drive the manufacture of such products abroad through a costly emissions trading system, then we not only damage European industry and not only European jobs, but we also damage the global climate.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for the effort they have put into this dossier. A complex dossier, a dossier in which everyone collaborated to give a long-term vision, improve the quality of the environment and contribute with an overall effort to the reduction of carbon emissions. Overall we have reached a good compromise. Perhaps there is still something to correct to ensure that some sectors can still find room for growth in Europe but, on the other hand, the line is drawn and I believe and I want to invite all political groups to support with the final vote, whatever they are the small changes made, a large legislative package that takes us on the path of the Paris agreement to achieve the long-term, ambitious objectives that we have defended in Parliament and that we will have to continue to negotiate with the Council, indicating a long-term path that it is an important road, that of the progressive decarbonisation of our economy and a better environment, in which we want our children and our descendants to live.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Directive 2003/87 / EC established a scheme for the marketing of greenhouse gas emission allowances in the Union in order to promote reductions in carbon dioxide emissions in a cost-effective and efficient manner. economic view. In the current review, we must also take into account the sustainable strengthening of the Union industry in terms of the risk of carbon leakage, investment and employment. I emphasize, therefore, that the aim of the directive is to achieve a level of emission reduction so that there are no relocations of carbon dioxide emissions and of investments and jobs. I would add here that it does not artificially increase the price of energy for European consumers, whether they are citizens or the manufacturing industry. Security of energy supply, together with the fight against climate change, is a primary policy objective of both Europe and the Member States. The revision of the ETS must strike a balance between reducing emissions, the real economic situation of the Member States, the need for the development of industry, including the energy sector, and the specificities of the different Member States. We need a predictable, efficient and stable regulatory framework for stimulating investment in low-carbon technologies without affecting the competitiveness of the ETS sectors and achieving the Paris targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The EU ETS matters for the future. Unfortunately, it shapes a negative investment climate in Europe, as entrepreneurs do not know what the price of allowances will be and how they will be protected against competition from third countries. Moreover, as proposed, the EU ETS will deepen carbon leakage, and thus job losses in the EU, and will worsen the living conditions of people living in poorer countries. However, there are also positive elements in this report. Thank you for appreciating the importance of district heating, which I have been striving for. Unfortunately, there are definitely more elements in the report that I cannot agree with. First of all, with restrictive increases in emission reduction rates, artificially raising the price of allowances, tampering with the market stability reserve and an incomprehensible attack on the cement sector, or an attempt to limit the operation of the compensation mechanisms that the Council has envisaged for the energy sector in poorer Member States.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! First of all, thank you very much to the rapporteur and other rapporteurs for their hard work. It is indeed a very important report. It will determine not only meeting our climate goals, but also whether the European economy defends itself, especially now, as some of the world's largest emitters are looking to withdraw from their Paris commitments. It is worth returning to the solutions proposed by the Industry Committee. I must very strongly emphasize some of these solutions, such as not increasing the linear emission reduction factor or the need for free allowances for cement producers. It is very important that we leave this modernization fund, which is important to many countries, in the hands of the beneficiary countries with the advice of the European Investment Bank. I repeat once again, if we really want to win the fight against climate change, we need Europe's economic strength to protect the climate, so let us take care of Europe's economic strength.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Madam President! It is only less than six months ago that we in this House ratified the Paris Agreement. Here, we welcomed Ban Ki-moon, and we committed the EU to reducing our emissions by at least 40% by 2030. And it is now that we must deliver on the commitments we agreed to. We can only do that if we reform the EU's quota trading system. Our goal should be that it should cost to pollute, it is the only way to ensure that companies have incentives to also make green investments. Right now, prices are so low that the quota trading system has almost no effect at all. It's a shame, it's bad for the climate. But we are changing that now, and with the proposal that is before Parliament, we are taking a really big step in the right direction. There is nothing in this system that is perfect, there is much that could be better, but by reforming the quota trading system, we are moving in that direction in favor of the climate. We will reduce the number of allowances by 2.4%, and we will ensure that the CO2 emissions in 2021 will actually be adjusted to the actual emissions that will be in 2021. Overall, this will mean that we will reduce emissions and that we also ensure that our industry becomes greener. It is necessary if we are to deliver on our commitments under the Paris Agreement, it is necessary if we are to secure our climate in the future.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the Paris climate agreement has had the great merit of paving the way for international awareness of climate change, and I hope it will last. We must therefore reduce our carbon footprint, otherwise the consequences could be very serious. This emission allowance market plays a fundamental role in this regard, since it will encourage the most polluting industries to constantly innovate and to think about ways of achieving growth rooted in our territories and respectful of our environment. European industry is one of the most successful in the world in this area and has already implemented increasingly high standards. This is why we have to stand with it, because we must not let it suffocate in the face of international competition and millions of jobs depend on it, and I cannot agree to let our industry suffer. Polluting more elsewhere is not an option. This is why we need to drive a real industrial strategy, while leading active climate diplomacy. In any case, I also expect the Member States to embark on this ambitious path.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in 2003 we approved the Emissions Trading Directive so that emission reductions could be made in a flexible, efficient way and without exposing our industry to unfair competition from third countries. This third element is especially important in the Mediterranean basin, which is much more exposed to maritime traffic and to competition from third countries. To give examples, we can put the cement. The important thing is not to create comparative grievances between industrial sectors due to a system design flaw. I know that the question is not easy, but it is necessary that the same conditions, burdens and privileges exist for sectors that have to compete in the same economic field. The issue of over-allocation is resolved in the report through a more dynamic mechanism of adaptation to production levels. I think that the collaboration of the ITRE and ENVI commissions has been good. I want to congratulate Mr Duncan and also thank Mr Belet for the great effort that he has made within the PPE Group.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, my colleagues! To be ambitious is sometimes not enough, you also have to find sensible solutions. And I think that the project worked out quite well. It is a huge achievement that we in Parliament have the strength to change five percent of the free allocation. That will not be easy in the Council. But this is an argument that is worthwhile and that is sensible. It is less wise if you introduce a new instrument at one point that has not been tested and of which you do not know whether it will have an effect, and thus hit an industry that is producing great figures, at least in Europe. It is not wise to punish someone who delivers really good CO2 figures, like the cement sector, to sanction now. In this respect, my request would be that you really correct it again at this point. Peter Liese has just described it precisely: We must try to equip this instrument, this market-based instrument, in such a way that it works and is also helpful to industry.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: -  Sir.Chairman!(sound missing)… an important decision, which will be put to the vote on Wednesday, and it is important that Europe remains competitive.We have a daunting task of reducing CO2 emissions, and then the driving forces of pragmatic forces in Europe must stand together with a clear signal that we want to deliver a more sustainable industry and a better climate.There will be a real cost to polluting, and the industry will have clear incentives to improve and innovate and get help for it.But no roses without thorns!Starting to regulate the shipping industry around the IMO is downright foolish and harmful in the long run.Border adjustment mechanism, it is not compatible with the WTO and it will be very detrimental to the cement industry - as also pointed out by other colleagues - we hope that the amendment can rectify this.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: - Madam President, colleagues. We have a huge challenge in Europe. On the one hand, it is important for us that the European economy develops. At the same time, we need to reduce CO2 emissions. We are well aware that very often these two objectives contradict each other, because, of course, the more we have economic activity, because somewhere we burn something more, and that is to the detriment of the climate with its CO2 emissions. This is a solution developed in the emissions trading system. We see that the system is not perfect. If it were perfect, it would not be the second time we have been forced to change it. And what happens when we change? We know that there are a lot of political compromises that may or may not be in the interests of the climate and / or the economy. So that is the goal - what more can we do to keep the industry afloat and the climate bad. Colleagues, I see only one long-term solution. Next time, I call on the Commission to seriously consider a carbon tax as a possible solution when we find again that the ET system is not doing what we want it to do. Turn away from the process, not the finished product: a transparent, easy-to-use system. What is needed is less policy. Thanks!

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, we are aware of and agree on the need to protect a healthy environment and the need to combat climate change, but we must be aware of the need to find a sustainable balance between environmental protection and industrial protection in the European Union. The dislocation of industry already done has caused damage to the industrial potential and the closure of many jobs in the European Union. Some amendments in the report are very harmful, especially on the 12th and 84th, for the cement sector in the Republic of Croatia and would cause the closure of all factories and the loss of 3,000 jobs. And in favor of competing, third countries, on the edge of the European Union, which equally pollute European air, and have no restrictions. The cement industry is most affected, not only in Croatia, but also in other countries: Portugal, Spain, Italy, Greece, Estonia and Ireland. In addition to the cement industry, the steel industry will be endangered because the standards and standards we set for the industry at the moment are technically unattainable, and their profitability would be called into question.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: - Madam President, what we are debating today and voting this week is the keystone of the system for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and polluting emissions. The ETS must be an ambitious instrument to meet the objectives of the fight against climate change; It should serve as an incentive for industries to develop cutting-edge technologies for reducing emissions; it should serve to strengthen European leadership in the fight against global warming. Yes, all of this is true. But our obligation is to promote norms that ensure balanced conditions for the affected industrial sectors; Our obligation is to promote economic activity, employment and the competitiveness of our industry, while encouraging its innovative capacity to reduce its emissions. Hence, ambition and balance. And that, of course, was the purpose of some of the amendments that I presented at the ITRE Committee. If we recover any of them, we will also recover ambition and balance.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - (NL) Madam President, but what should the European emissions trading system look like after 2020? Well, in any case, I am glad that the Environment Committee has tightened up the proposals of the European Commission. Because the current advance on rights is reminiscent of the milk puddles and butter mountains of yesteryear, and that was actually a sign of failing European policy. So it shouldn't go that way. Shipping can no longer be left out. I prefer a global scheme, but I also support the big stick that is now included in the text. The shipping sector has until 2021 to reach a worldwide agreement for the reduction of CO2 within the framework of the International Maritime Organization, but if that does not work, the European Union will take up this. Aviation made agreements in 2016 on a global emissions trading system that will start voluntarily in 2020 and become mandatory in 2027. Here too, Europe must lead the way, auction allowances and reduce emissions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, unfortunately, instead of having the primary objective of protecting the environment and enhancing the quality of life of the people, the Emissions Trading Scheme is, in fact, seeking to grant free rights to large industries as an incentive to remain in the Union. So we will not support the commercialization of emissions, which, in the final analysis, favors the big multinationals to increase their profits, even though they are also the main culprits of climate change. We will not support a system that, as has been shown, in no way contributes to reducing emissions. Especially when today, in the midst of an economic crisis, small and medium-sized local industries should be supported, especially in the countries of Southern Europe, which have been hit hardest by memoranda and austerity policies. That is why we have tabled a specific amendment to protect the cement industry, which in the South is one of the main export industries, to protect thousands of jobs while protecting the environment. Because, otherwise, we give an advantage to industries from third countries.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, esteemed colleagues, four months ago, in this same hall, we adopted a Resolution by which we signed or accepted the Paris Agreement and enabled it to enter into force. What does this emissions trading system actually provide us with? If we have one robust and stable system, we have actually provided a way of financing to ensure that transition from dirty energy to clean energy. However, I would now like to look at the consequences, that is, the modernization fund, which should enable this transition to take place. Here I would like to draw the attention of our esteemed Commissioner Cañete to what is actually happening in the European Union. So we all need to play an equal role in reducing CO2 emissions, no matter what Member State we live in. However, if we look at underdeveloped Member States in Eastern and South-Eastern Europe, capital investment in clean technology and renewable energy is much higher than in other Member States. So, an unequal relationship when we talk about investments in clean energy.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Madam President, the Committee on the Environment proposal to reduce emissions by up to 40% by 2030 for the European Union includes, inter alia, the exclusion of cement from the list of carbon leaks, as well as the future installation of a compensation mechanism for importers. If this proposal is accepted, there will be a big problem in the cement industry and trade, because, by introducing strict emission reduction rules in the developed countries of the European Union, we are creating carbon leakage, ie moving production to other countries for which they do not apply. these strict restrictions and which therefore become more competitive. This will have devastating consequences for the cement industry in Europe and especially for Greece, because the operation of four or even five of the six cement plants in the country will be jeopardized, which should not happen because many thousands will be lost. jobs. We therefore vote against this proposal, even if it upsets the dear rapporteur who is celebrating his birthday today.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, a Happy Birthday to Ian Duncan and a thank you to him and all colleagues who have worked so intensively on the dossier. I say yes to climate protection, but I also say yes to keeping our jobs in the European Union. Because it is of no use to the climate if our jobs are relocated abroad. But that is exactly what would threaten if the vote of the Environment Committee on the so-called alternative border adjustment is confirmed in the plenary. These border adjustment measures would hit certain sectors particularly hard, including the cement industry, the brick industry and the lime industry. These works threaten to lose their free allocation. Why should we punish these industries, these factories, and thereby also endanger our jobs? I myself have a cement plant or several plants in my chosen region, like many other colleagues. I visit these plants every year and see what investments have been made there in terms of energy efficiency, process optimization and CO2 reduction. So please, let's make sure that these industries don't migrate!

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, the report is the first step towards meeting the objectives we agreed on at COP21 in Paris to tackle climate change. However, I would like to address an important issue, the base year set by the European Commission for the introduction of the Modernization Fund. The condition for a country to participate in this Fund is that its GDP is below 60% of the European average in 2013. Greece was just over 60%, while from 2014 onwards it is below the threshold. The choice of 2013 as the calculation year for a Fund that will start operating in 2021 makes no sense and is deeply unfair. With amendment 149 that I tabled, in cooperation with my fellow MEPs, we call for 2014 and 2015 to be defined as base years. A Fund, which aims at solidarity, cannot exclude countries that are in such a crisis as Greece. That is why I ask you to support us. It is, basically, a matter of solidarity with Greece.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, having had the honour of representing Parliament both in Paris and Marrakech, I am totally committed to the targets set out in Paris. I think the message has to go out loud and clear, to every single Member State and country and every sector, that there is no escape. However, there is a difference between that and people saying we should increase ambition in Europe, especially in view of what is happening across the pond. We cannot be naive, and naivety is when we have carbon leakage leading to the loss of jobs in Europe and increased emissions worldwide. That makes no sense. So for that reason I back my colleagues, particularly in the PPE Group and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, regarding cement. Having a different policy for one sector is not good policy making, so I hope we can adjust that. Also I welcome the qualitative assessment being reduced to 1.2, and hopefully that can be done at Prodcom rather than NACE-4 level. We are not looking for a free pass for any sector, but every sector is entitled to sit the exam. I hope we get it right and that we then have a strong position for trilogues.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, in this debate today, many Members have expressed concern about certain industries, especially the cement industry.I myself am of the opinion that, although the arguments that have been listed here by colleagues are true, it must also be seen that this industry actually has an awful lot of reduction potential.In that sense, I really want to support those efforts, and I consider these parts of the report to be of great value, which focus primarily on technological development.I am convinced that our competitiveness, not in terms of technological closure, of conserving existing technologies, is in terms of innovation, so that Europe will not be vulnerable to the rest of the world.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would first like to thank all the MEPs who spoke in this debate, raising issues that are important not only for European climate policy broadly but also for our citizens and businesses. Forging agreements on the different aspects of the European Union’s Emissions Trading System (ETS) ambition has been a very challenging task. I therefore reiterate my gratitude to Ian Duncan and Fredrick Federley, as well as to the Chairs of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Jerzy Buzek, and Adina-Ioana Vălean, for all the efforts they made to deliver this excellent and ambitious report. But all the work done may become meaningless if, on Wednesday, Parliament is unable to give ample support to this report. We need a very strong position from Parliament in order to start inter-institutional negotiations with the Council. I am confident that, in view of all the challenges facing us in climate policy, there will be in this House the same degree of responsibility and spirit of compromise that we found in Paris in December 2015. That is what European citizens expect from all of us.

name: Ian Duncan
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you very much to everyone who has taken part in the debate today. I can think of nowhere I would rather be for my birthday than right here, right now. I know that I have not made everyone happy but I think I have shared a little bit of unhappiness across the whole spectrum, and that will be the challenge for all of us – recognising that we have to take a little bit of unhappiness. Let me make a few points which are worth making. The Emissions Trading System (ETS) is not working well right now: that is the first point. The second point: Paris changes everything. The third point: we need to offer to our industry sensible protection but we must expect from them sensible efforts as well. It is also important that this is a stepping stone to a serious trilogue. I was trying to think of a way of combining all of these points with regard to their urgency. I too was in Marrakech for the climate change talks. By the middle of the week I had clearly eaten something which I found a little bit unsettling. Halfway between the conference centre and my hotel I was faced with a serious choice: I could try and go backwards and hope that I made it in time or I could try to go forwards to get to my hotel and try to make sure that I got there without soiling myself. In fact, that is what we have before us right now. The real challenge is to get to our hotel and get to that lavatory because we have got to avoid making a mess. The real danger we have tonight is if we are not able to find that compromise, then we will make a mess. It is time now to move forward. There is a compromise on the table and we have got to get there. Thank you for your contributions. Thank you for joining me for my birthday, and let us get the deal done.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday February 15, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. - We undoubtedly support the policies on climate change adopted by the Paris Agreement and we believe that the European Union can make the greatest contribution in this direction. At the same time, however, we consider it particularly important to have a balanced approach to the issue, so that the effort to reduce greenhouse gases and environmental impacts is accompanied by the protection of the secondary production sector, industry and small and medium-sized enterprises. There was therefore a need to protect both the competitiveness and viability of European companies and valuable jobs. To this end, we supported the amendments that were in the right direction and ensured the competitiveness of the cement companies of the Mediterranean countries.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: in writing. - Before we start talking about any reform of this EU pseudo-market ETS system, we should conduct a detailed analysis of what the current system has provided. There is no such analysis. This highly criticized system is unfair to the "less economically disadvantaged" countries. It is an unequal burden on the citizens of the Member States. The following questions arise: 1. Why is the ETS not internally coherent? Why is it not related to energy efficiency and the share of RES? 2. Why is this system so unilaterally restrictive and does not take into account the possibility of earning thanks to the capture and absorption of CO2? 3. Why is it not considering heating and cooling strategies as the most effective way to reduce CO2 emissions? 4. Shouldn't we set emission benchmarks, the so-called benchmarks, at the national level? We need a fundamental discussion. This is a problem for the industry of many Member States, for which the current Commission proposals may pose a Hamlet's "be or not be" dilemma. Let us not rush to apply a system that has not worked so far.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: signed up. - Making the reduction of emissions profitable by increasing investment is the aim of amending the directive. It is important to strike a balance between the proposed emission targets and the investment opportunities so as not to jeopardize jobs. Member States have a security of electricity supply on their agenda. Preventing Member States from supporting the generation mix they prefer would be against the spirit of the EU. I believe that there is a need to simplify the governance of the Modernization Fund, which should primarily be controlled by the beneficiary Member States in accordance with the ITRE opinion. The accelerated decline in certificates could affect energy security in the EU. The purpose of amending the Directive is to reduce emissions, not to set a higher price for emissions. Let's not forget the products of other continents, which are much more polluting than Europe, and the fact that we can deindustrialize Europe even more.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - The success of European climate policy is in the common interest of all of us. Just as air pollution does not stop at borders, so we are not able to deal with this problem individually, we need to work together and find a common solution. However, we must be careful throughout this struggle in order to carry out a truly successful transformation, while protecting the European economy and preserving European jobs. It is in this spirit that the concept of the Modernization Fund has been formulated, according to which those Member States that will be exposed to the most additional costs due to the new rules will be entitled to a share of the proceeds from quota sales to develop and modernize their obsolete assets. In my opinion, the administrative structure for the Modernization Fund set out in the ENVI Committee is opaque and dangerous. A well-prepared system of criteria can adequately enforce common expectations, and an overly complicated administrative structure is unnecessary. It also violates the principle of subsidiarity and creates further tensions by entrusting parties not involved in the assessment of projects, thus separating decision-making and implementation. In the spirit of all this, I ask my fellow Members to support our amendment to improve the transparency and efficiency of the Modernization Fund.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. - The parliamentary negotiations on the ETS directive on emission allowances for European industrial installations, which have been going on for a year and a half, have been the subject of intense debate. An important element of the reform of the European Emissions Trading Scheme is the regulation of the division of EU responsibilities arising from the Paris Climate Agreement, the increase of the level of ambition, which may further increase the spread of low-emission technologies and the transition to a carbon-free economy in Europe. However, in addition to ensuring that environmental objectives are met, the legitimate interests of the productive sector must also be taken into account throughout the negotiations, as the displacement of energy-intensive sectors could put Europe at a competitive disadvantage. It is also important to avoid placing a disproportionate burden on some players in the European industrial sector, while giving others undue advantages. I hope that the plenary vote will lead the report in the right direction and that a balanced parliamentary mandate will be adopted before the trialogues, properly reflecting the above considerations. Finally, I think it is important to emphasize that the part of the Committee on the Environment's text relating to the Modernization Fund severely restricts the decision-making freedom of the beneficiary countries in Central and Eastern Europe. The draft report is not in line with the political agreement reached in the October 2014 European Council conclusions, so my colleagues and I tabled an individual amendment to ensure that the governance structure of the Modernization Fund adequately reflects the interests of the beneficiary Member States.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - Climate policies must go hand in hand with maintaining existing and creating new jobs. That is why it is extremely important to achieve the right balance in meeting the emission reduction targets and to maintain the competitiveness of the industry. The sectors most at risk of carbon leakage and relocation to third countries must receive sufficient free allowances to prevent job losses and negative effects on the economy. I also believe that the rules need to be simplified for small businesses that emit small amounts of greenhouse gases in order to reduce the administrative burden on them. I believe that it is important for countries with lower gross domestic product to be financially supported in order to modernize energy systems and improve their energy efficiency. These incentives must be provided through clear and as simple as possible procedures, which give Member States the freedom to determine the projects to receive funding.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – The emissions trading system (ETS) is the principal instrument for lowering emissions in the sectors that it covers. The ETS has continuously been enhanced to tackle the changing environmental and economic realities. The current reform is vital for meeting the ambitious targets set in the Paris Agreement and enhancing the effectiveness of the ETS in long-term. Parliament must set a clear path towards successful negotiations with the Council whilst maintaining the balanced approach between industrial competitiveness and climate goals.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: signed up. - The Commission's new proposal for the EU ETS scheme is needed, as this reform must provide some certainty for industry and investors in Eastern Europe by setting rules in the period after 2021. It is also an opportunity to increase energy efficiency and support actions. climate. We do not want the European economy to face a relocation of energy-intensive industries to third countries. Free allocation of green certificates is essential for industries on the carbon leakage risk list. Flexibility in the number of free quotas compared to bids is very important for the long-term sustainability of the EU ETS. The Commission must take into account, in using the Innovation Fund, industries striving to invest in new technologies in order to find innovative ways for the future. The modernization fund is welcome and it must be possible for it to be regulated by the beneficiary Member State and taking into account national circumstances. Aviation, road transport, agricultural waste and buildings should continue to be non-ETS sectors. Member States must have the necessary framework to set their own national climate targets, taking into account the energy production conditions specific to each Member State.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: In written form. - Ladies and gentlemen, we are all convinced that the emissions trading scheme needs to be adjusted for the next period after 2020 in order to become more effective in achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement. But we must not forget that imposing too great restrictions on Europe's energy-intensive industries will lead to their displacement in countries with lower requirements, to the loss of jobs and income, but not to the reduction of emissions on a global scale. Let us take into account the fact that the EU contributes only 10% of global CO2 emissions and whether we reduce them to 7% or 6% by 2030 will not solve the global problem, but it could cause irreparable damage to our own economy. Therefore, it is not justified to accept emission reduction factors and factors that threaten the existence of certain sectors in European industry. I therefore welcome the return of texts from the ITRE Committee's opinion, which are significantly more balanced and to a much greater extent protect the sectors and sub-sectors at risk of our industry. I certainly support the relief for countries with lower gross domestic product to receive free emission allowances, but let us not introduce such conditions for the use of this aid that make it practically non-functioning.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Tibor Szanyi, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on European Union competition policy (2016/2100 (INI)) (A8-0001 / 2017).

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: performer. - Thank you very much, Madam President, and thank you for the work and cooperation of the shadow rapporteurs. In my opinion, this time we have managed to create a comprehensive, very substantive report, which is an excellent complement to the material of the European Commission, with many suggestions and comments. The report reaffirms the role of EU competition policy as an essential tool for creating a strong and efficient internal market, as well as a key policy for economic growth, innovation, resource efficiency and the European social market economy. Europe's future is based on these elements, and guaranteeing a level playing field is critical. The report, which covers a number of topics, also shows two points, namely across chapters. One is the social dimension, as we considered it important to remind Member States of the extent to which strictly complied with but also socially sensitive competition policy rules can have a positive impact on the lives of European citizens, consumers, workers and businesses. The other is the subject of tax justice. We reaffirm our commitment to tax justice, which is essential for the integrity of the European single internal market, and emphasize that all market participants must pay their share of the tax, where that profit has been made. The report acknowledges the need to put an end to unfair tax competition between Member States, as well as to aggressive tax planning, illegal tax optimization and selective tax incentives that make it impossible for the main sources of innovation, small and medium-sized enterprises. I am glad that the pursuit of tax justice has become such an important part of the report, as it is an essential condition for a fair competitive environment. In addition, the text calls for fiscal convergence, which would significantly strengthen the Union's economic cohesion and competitiveness. In addition to tax issues, we also focus on the digital single market. We also underline the role of small and medium-sized enterprises in the digital single market, which is why the report commends the Commission's investigations into anti-competitive practices by internet and telecoms giants. With regard to the digital single market, I considered it important to highlight the issue of shared businesses. This economic model has been in place for a number of years and offers a number of innovative products and services to EU consumers. It is not an easy situation for the Commission when many people want to mix the same services together. And although we all know, but for the sake of example, I will mention that Uber is not a taxi and Airbnb is not a hotel. These are platforms, which, however, would have to pay tax in the same way as the service providers who use them. The report also advocates the paramount importance of net neutrality and confirms that, although a very important step, the elimination of roaming charges within the EU is not enough: intra-EU calls must be regulated at the same level as local calls. That is why our report calls on the Commission to put forward a legislative proposal to regulate calls within the EU. With regard to state aid, the report emphasizes the increased responsibility of Member States to the Commission for aid granted without prior notification. In addition, we emphasize that temporary state aid in the financial sector was needed to stabilize the global financial system, but it must be reduced as soon as possible or completely abolished and monitored as soon as the banking union is fulfilled. I also consider it important to underline some other points in the report. Corruption in public procurement procedures has a serious market-distorting effect on European competitiveness. Energy and in the case of environmental investments, they may be particularly detrimental and adversely affect the proper functioning of the Energy Union and the achievement of the Union's environmental objectives. Accordingly, we urge in the report that all state aid related to energy and environmental investments and all irregularities related to public procurement procedures, such as the disputed expansion project of the Hungarian Paks Nuclear Power Plant, be closely monitored and thoroughly investigated. The report also discusses the importance of transport infrastructure and addresses the interests of consumers and producers, thus taking particular account of the special situation of the agri-food sector and paying close attention to enhanced cooperation between national competition authorities. I therefore believe that the text points as far as possible to the shortcomings of competition policy, both to the Member States and to the Union. I am convinced that, through the recommendations and calls, the Member States can make a significant contribution to economic growth, the creation of quality jobs, innovation, the development of small and medium-sized enterprises and tax justice.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the House very much for inviting me here today and I would especially like to thank Mr Szanyi for his draft report. I think it sums up very well why competition matters. As it says, competition policy is the cornerstone of the single market. It should make it work. State-aid rules give every company a fair chance to compete, and anti-trust and merger rules make sure that the markets serve the public, not just big companies. Last year we found that four truck companies, well actually five truck makers, which together sold nine out of every ten medium and heavy trucks in Europe, had colluded for 14 years to raise gross list prices and delay the launch of green technology.  This sort of cartel can make a lot of money for the companies involved. It is their customers who pay the price. So it takes firm action to make sure that companies have nothing to gain by breaking the rules. That is why we fined those five companies, five businesses, nearly EUR 3 billion, the largest cartel fine in the Commission’s history. Meanwhile, our case is continuing against a sixth company that would not settle.
