But enforcing these rules throughout Europe has to be a team effort, involve national competition authorities as well as the Commission and that can only be effective if everyone has the powers that they need. So I fully agree with your recommendation that we should propose EU legislation to make sure that they have the right powers. We have had the same message from our consultations and our impact assessment. So we are now working on a proposal that I hope to be able to present before summer and I firmly expect that we can fully involve Parliament. As well as anti-trust cases we deal with mergers that are reshaping global industries, like the one that will now reduce the six biggest producers of seeds and pesticides to just three. These transactions can affect each and every one of us because seeds and pesticides, crop protection, they are the beginning of the food chain. It is important that this sector continues to develop new products that correspond to the regulatory requirements in Europe and that they will sell these products at competitive prices. It is important for farmers, for the consumer and obviously for the environment. That is why my services are looking into these mergers in great detail. Each of them will be assessed on their own merits and will only be allowed to proceed if they do not impose any impediment to effective competition. When it comes to state aids our cases on tax rulings show that no company, however big and powerful, can avoid paying its fair share of taxes. I fully share the approach in your draft report. We have taken four final decisions, so far, that deal with illegal state aid through tax rulings. Of course, these decisions are based on the evidence and the rule of law. And we have taken forward more cases involving Amazon, McDonald’s and Engie in exactly the same spirit.  At the same time we will continue our investigation into tax rulings in every Member State. And we are always ready to work with Member States to make sure that state aid does not come up in the future. It is good to see that Luxembourg has brought in much stricter rules on the taxation of financing companies. We were happy to discuss that with the national authorities and we are happy to do that with anyone that wants to. When it comes to banks our state-aid rules are there to support troubled banks when it comes to the same terms throughout Europe. We apply the same rules, in the same way, to every bank, in every Member State. Now European banks are far more stable than they were a decade ago. But in spite of the improvements some banks in Europe are still struggling to deal with non-performing loans from defaulting borrowers and the Commission is working with those Member States and banks where non-performing loans remain to help banks gradually reduce them. European banks need to put the legacy of the crisis firmly behind them. Last but not least, renewable energy is important – just thinking about the debate you have just had. Competition can help us bring down the cost of our transition. Since the start of this year all new support for large renewable plants has had to be given through a tender. Pilot tenders have already shown how much we could save. In Germany tenders have brought down the price of supporting solar energy by 25% in the last year and a half.  Meanwhile the sector inquiry report on capacity mechanism, which we published in November, will help Member States to keep down costs on making sure that there is electricity when demand needs it.  If the costs of funding renewable energy would make an energy intensive sector like the steel sector uncompetitive, well, state-aid rules do not stop a Member State compensating that part of the cost, because the competition rules are here to support European competitiveness, not to undermine it. An open single market with fair competition, well, that helped to cut the cost of input and it helped businesses to grow big enough to compete throughout the world and this is what we want to see and to do. And through our free trade agreements, including the agreement with Canada, we are encouraging countries around the world to reduce subsidies and to use subsidies more responsibly because competition works.  This is the message of our enforcement work and I think it is also the message of your report. I welcome it and I am very happy for the support. Because the Commission will keep working to enforce the competition rules, taking forward the three Google cases and continuing to work on the case against Gazprom so consumers and businesses do not pay inflated prices for gas. We will use all our powers to make sure that the single market remains open and fair and in that, of course, we need to work together. Thank you very much for your draft report.

name: Adam Szejnfeld
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Foreign Trade. Madam President! We are talking about the past, but we must relate to the future. And here one must remember that there is no free market, no good development without fair competition. This, however, is disturbed by many unfavorable factors. We can point to particularisms, local, regional, but also national - they also affect our common single market. Another issue is state aid. Unequal treatment of private and state-owned or state-owned companies, the functioning of natural monopolies, for example in the field of utilities, sensitive sectors - primarily energy, transport, telecommunications, public procurement, financial services - and finally international trade. This is a separate issue, but very important, because we should and must also transfer our principles of fair competition to our trading and investment partners around the world.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - Madam President, Commissioner! First of all, as is customary here, I would like to thank the rapporteur and our shadow rapporteur, Fulvio Martusciello. In a minute, I will not be able to re-mention all the issues that have been dealt with very well and based on consensus in the report. I believe that, with all the good work that the Commission is doing, there is simply a very big difference in the fact that, on the one hand, we have the cases in the very classic, analogue internal market where the work can be carried on successfully as always in the classic way But let's just get on with it, and that you, Commissioner, have to deal with the question of what we can do in markets that are simply developing so quickly that decisions, when they are made years later, cannot bring that back. what has arisen in the distortion of competition, in the unfairly implemented distortion of competition. That is a difficult question, and when it comes to drawing up the budget in the European Parliament, we keep thinking about whether we need more staff in DG Competition. I think this question arises again today. Secondly, Commissioner, I would like to draw your attention again to a problem in the competition report which concerns tourism, where we simply have state authorities that are publicly funded, but where there are difficulties with the state aid regime. I would be grateful for an examination here.

name: Michel Dantin
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Madam President, Commissioner, the report on the application of competition law, drawn up by our colleague Tibor Szanyi, is an important report and I want to thank him for his collaboration in our work. This report sets a precedent because it is the first time that the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has spoken on this subject. It is all the more setting a precedent as the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has been widely adopted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Commissioner, the current situation of crisis in agricultural markets and increased price volatility obliges us today to make ambitious proposals to adapt competition law to the agricultural market. Still in the field last week, I want to testify that the agricultural world expects concrete and rapid responses from us on rebalancing relationships within the food chain. We must therefore have the courage to lead this debate on competition law in the agricultural sector without populism but also without ideology. Your appearance on 28 February next to the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, with Commissioner Hogan, will be an opportunity to explore this subject in greater depth and I am at your disposal in this regard.

name: Fulvio Martusciello
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you must understand that there are too many instruments that distort competition in Europe and it is enough to read this dossier to understand it. This dossier, which started with the Commission with a few pages, arrives in this House with over 30 pages. In every article, in every point of this dossier, there is an element that must make the Commission think, because competition in Europe is distorted by so many factors. So we hope that all the indications given to the Commission are respected. I like to remember that, for the first time, in this dossier we establish that the boycott is an instrument of falsification and distortion of competition and is an element that must be sanctioned and taken up again. Commissioner, we have identified an element of great falsification of competition in the identification and payment of tolls that are charged to taxpayers and citizens to get out of the city walls. This phenomenon is frequent in Italy - for example on the Naples ring road you have to pay one euro to get out of the city - and you want to replicate it in other ring roads in our country. Commissioner, we are submitting this dossier with all the information and we are sure that you will enforce it.

name: Anneliese Dodds
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –  Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for everything she is doing, particularly around tax justice. I would also like to thank Mr Szanyi for his excellent report and my colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs who decided to support me in calling on the Commission to investigate competition in Formula One. Colleagues, you may think Formula One is just for petrol-headed adrenaline junkies but actually it is important for our economy as well. In ‘Motorsport Valley’, which stretches from the southeast of England into the Midlands, motorsports provide around 40 000 jobs. These are at risk. A few weeks ago, one team, Manor Racing, became the latest to collapse after administrators could not find a buyer. Smaller teams in Formula One are punished by rules that guarantee bigger teams prize money, even if they finish last. Recently the regulator of Formula One, the FIA, made a USD 79.5 million profit by selling its stake in the sport – a stake it had promised the Commission it would not take on. We must stop the haemorrhage of jobs from this sector and keep a sport loved by 500 million fans as it should be – truly competitive.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, I would like to speak specifically about the banks tonight. In 2008-2009, special state aid rules were approved by the European Commission, which must allow Member States to rescue their banks. This European Parliament has actually been asking for six years that we end this temporary state aid completely. That is also the logic of the new rules of the banking union, that we will opt for bail-ins instead of bail-outs in the future. Because what are we seeing in Italy today? That the rules were first bypassed and now they are even simply ignored. And that creates a lot of annoyance among the population, a lot of anger about those bail-outs of the banks. But what do we see? That enormous profits have been built up in the past and that they have ended up with the wealthy bankers, while the losses have to be borne by the common people, by the taxpayers, and that is no longer possible. Look, I don't mind if people earn a good living by working hard, but then they also have to bear the risks and the losses. We need more responsibility. And I also call on the Commissioner to continue to work hard on this.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, colleagues and the rapporteur for their cooperation. This report talks about many things – airports, state aid – and asks us, as in other years, for more financial and human resources for DG Competition because there is a lot more work to be done. But I want to focus here on the Google case because, seven years after the Commission announced allegations of antitrust violations by Google, we have a spent a lot of time on this. Certainly, EU regulatory time does not correspond to the necessity and urgency of the companies in the real economy.  I am aware, Commissioner, that a lot of time was lost by your predecessor, Mr Almunia. These years of unproductive settlements, discussions and delays in the still-ongoing investigations have left competitiveness in the online search market severely damaged. But, at a certain point, a decision has to be made one way or another. That is why, in this report, we call on the Commission to finish all Google antitrust investigations. Let me recall two recent facts. Last December, Foundem, the first complainant in the shopping case, had to close its shopping comparison website, and Yelp also closed its European businesses. This is how the behaviour of Google impacts on companies. Ms Vestager, may I suggest to you that your provisional decision, which I hope will come in the next weeks or months, should impose a record—breaking fine on Google. You need to show companies that they cannot be rewarded for losing time because, in the last two years, Google’s attitude and behaviour has caused more damage to complainant companies. When it comes to remedies, may I suggest that all companies sit down with their technological experts, together with the Commission, to try to find non—discriminating future-proofed remedies. Thank you very much. Let me remind you that time helps monopolies and damages SMEs.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I am pleased that agricultural issues are acquiring a central relevance in this Parliament's conception of competition policy. This has been a priority of our Group since the beginning of the legislature: the fight against oligopolies of distribution and commercialization companies, which obtain juicy profits at the cost of food speculation and the exploitation of small farmers. As pointed out in the report, tighter supervision of agricultural markets, with the participation of representative organizations, is necessary to stop the plundering of the European countryside. We value positively the references to the fight against fiscal dumping, the denunciation - once again, at our initiative - of the plundering of Spanish preferentialists, or the need to fight against the pharmaceutical oligopoly. But nevertheless, I think the report is too accommodating. I am concerned that, dazzled by the fight against tax deals - which are limited, for the moment, to a handful of companies and which have not demanded political responsibilities from Messrs Juncker or Dijsselbloem - we are whitewashing the reality of a policy that, Today as yesterday, it was designed to deregulate and privatize markets, leaving large companies, and not the public sector, to define the future of strategic sectors. The single market has become a steamroller for social rights, privatizing and deregulating railways and ports, opening the way for digital operators such as Airbnb or Hoover, or protecting speculation by the large electricity operators.

name: Michel Reimon
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Thank you, Commissioner, for your report and for always dealing so openly with Parliament here. Thanks also to the rapporteur for this very good report and also for the two priorities that I can only support, both tax competition and digital issues. Indeed, these are important areas that we have to deal with. I would like to point out three other issues. The first is a question that will come to us, that will come to you, Commissioner: the Bayer-Monsanto deal that is coming up. If that happens, the world's largest seed and crop protection company will emerge. Then we have to quickly check whether a monopoly situation arises here, which would mean a major problem for agriculture, for farmers, for seeds, for diversity and not just for competition. I would ask you to come here for the exam in 2017 very quickly. The second case is Paks, the nuclear power plant, where it is still not clear whether the aid, the loan that Putin is granting and which is to be repaid, violates competition law or not. We should come to a decision as quickly as possible in the interests of the whole of Europe. The third topic that is close to my heart is booking.com, the booking platform that distorts competition in the hotel sector in Europe. Individual nation states have already undertaken tests. We should come to a European solution. The importance of this digital area has already been mentioned several times. We should really invest a lot of resources there.

name: Marco Zanni
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have read the rapporteur's report carefully and have listened to what my colleagues have said today in plenary, who have focused on some individual problems of individual sectors and some cases relating to their countries. But I believe that, once again, the opportunity has been lost to go to the general problem, to the structural problem of competition within the European Union. Within this system, the term competition translates into the ruthless competition of the strongest who makes the rules and molds them according to his own system on the weakest. Competition within this single market is highly distorted by the rules and has destructive effects on the economies of weaker countries. Some examples: the first, the most obvious is the single currency which creates distorted competition between countries that enjoy a devalued effective exchange rate and therefore, to help their industrial system, can export their products more easily and more affordable, and countries that have to operate with a real exchange rate that is too high for the strength of their economy. Another issue where competition is distorted is that of banks, on state aid. A country like Italy is criticized for the weakness of its banking system and has to knock and deal with the Commission for a few billion euros, to save citizens' savings and instead, before and after 2008, larger countries gave hundreds billions of euros to save their banking systems: four hundred billion in Germany between direct and indirect guarantees, about 200 billion in France and the United Kingdom. This is not fair competition. Even on the issue of banking union, there is no competition. A distorting system of rules that rewards a more risky business model, such as that of derivatives and level 3 assets, which are not adequately considered by the Commission and that of credits which are instead punished.If the European Union goes on like this, destruction is inevitable.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Madam President, the Union's competition policy has achieved representative results, such as Brexit, the Volkswagen, Ferrostaal, Deutsche Telekom, Siemens scandals and the Luxembourg tax haven. It flooded Europe with illegal immigrants to find cheap labor, without insurance and employment rights. This is not a Union, but an amateur factory. Unfair competition between companies prevails and policies are imposed in the interest of specific states. It pushes small and medium-sized enterprises to move their headquarters to other countries, as is the case with many Greek companies. A framework for business development support must be created, without abusive terms. This leads to balance, prosperity and peace. A simple example is the implementation of a low corporate tax policy, with tax rates on profits and a grace period for new or innovative businesses. But this is not achieved by authoritarian and selfish politicians. Just give up! There are better and more honest people, more capable of taking on this role.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I very much hope that in a few years we will be talking simply about the single market, and not about an analogue or digital single market. Since that time has not yet arrived, I would like to base my remarks on competition policy with regard to the digital single market. Without fair competition policy there is no digital single market. Competition not only gives consumers more choice but should also provide the level playing field that is needed so that start-ups will scale up in Europe and not elsewhere. The online world is expected to create more competition in Europe. Therefore, it is crucial to improve access to goods and services, to eliminate unlawful obstacles to online competition and to ensure that online shopping is barrier free. Only then will we be able to stop the building of monopolies and prevent illegal access to content. Ending unjustified geo-blocking practices is one concrete step in the right direction but I believe it should be done in a way that does not hamper SMEs and start-ups, and does not raise prices for consumers, especially in newer Member States. This is one of the many reasons why I believe national competition authorities should work together with the Commission. I also believe that, in order fully to guarantee competition, the principle of neutrality should be strictly followed. Finally, in a particularly dynamic sector such as the digital economy, we need swift enforcement and competition policy rules that create a friendly business ecosystem, nourishing new business models and supporting innovation at all levels.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we always needed to make a crucial point regarding the Commission’s annual competition report. Competition rules, especially for state aid, should not be applied on a one-size-fits-all basis – that still holds. But during this mandate the need is arising to highlight new precautionary signals.  Firstly, European competition policy should avoid the appearance of a frontal contest with other administrations via the application of huge two-way fines on a tit-for-tat basis. Secondly, applying state-aid rules to the tax policies of Member States may help to combat tax avoidance, but it overrides the tax sovereignty that Member States still have under the Treaties. The flexibility of Member States in setting their tax policies has to be confirmed. Thirdly, there should be concern about a competition policy that is administered through an agency which defines such policy, investigates alleged breaches and itself decides on them with the power to set fines. Fourthly, given the ongoing current political and economic changes in Europe and beyond, competition policy needs to be kept under constant review. If Europe is going to be more Catholic than the Pope it risks losing competitive edge on a global scale.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, competition is the only real guarantee of the strength of the European economy and that is why I support any initiative that seeks to eliminate redundant regulation and ensure an equal market position for all economic operators, both small and large.I agree with the report in that part in which it calls for a simple and transparent tax policy and emphasizes public procurement as particularly vulnerable to corruption.But I cannot agree with the calls for harmonization of tax rates across the EU because I believe that competition should not only exist between companies, but also between countries.Harmonization of tax rates will cement the existing situation and will prevent less developed members from reaching the more developed ones.For example, how will a Croatia, with a poorer judiciary and infrastructure and fewer skilled workers, ever compete with Germany if it has the same tax rates?Who will invest in Croatia near Germany if there is no financial benefit from it?

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Good evening, Commissioner! As you can see in this report, there is broad support for EU competition policy being a very, very important tool. We actually like to see even more things added. I would like to highlight two things. I believe that the Commission needs more competences and resources to ensure that our competition policy is implemented in a proper way, for example by setting up more permanent travel teams, task forces that can go around investigating suspicions. about unfair competition, not only in the large sectors, not only where there is big at stake, but also where there are smaller cases at stake in the smaller sectors. Competition policy is important. Then I also wanted us to take a closer look at whether we could use the consumer compensation rules in competition policy as well. There are areas where cartel fines cannot be imposed, but where we may be able to provide better consumer compensation. For example, we have seen it in dieselgate where consumers have lost and nothing has happened. Here, perhaps, something could also be done to ensure fair competition. But in any case, thank you for a great effort.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Article 42 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union specifies that the competition rules apply to the production and trade of agricultural products only to the extent that the European Parliament and the Council determine it. In terms of competition, the tools of the CAP must take precedence over other regulations. Furthermore, I would like to recall the demand made on several occasions by Parliament for the establishment of a legislative framework to combat unfair commercial practices. It is urgent that competition law no longer poses a threat to farmers and their producer organizations. This is the responsibility of the European Commission. When we know the imbalance in the balance of power between production and distribution in the food distribution chain, taxing farmers as the endiviers of cartels is strictly unacceptable. It is important that Parliament is heard on this issue while respecting the preparation of the future common agricultural policy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a fair competition policy is essential for the proper functioning of the single market, which, as you know, still has problems. The Commission has recently identified several cases of multinationals stealing billions of euros in tax revenue from national budgets, sometimes with the complicity of the Member States themselves. These incidents cause alarm and require a detailed examination of the alleged cases of state aid and the immediate cessation of ad hoc fiscal stratagems. The Commission needs to continue investigating anti-competitive practices in the online digital sector and speed up procedures regarding antitrust action and tax issues, so as to ensure that SMEs and digital startups can operate in a more balanced and fair sphere of competition. , within a market often conditioned by multinational giants of digital technologies. The Commission must take effective action to safeguard competition in the telecommunications and energy sector to encourage affordable prices and service choices.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, in order for competition to work properly in the European Union, unfavorable conditions must not be imposed on European industry in relation to the global reality, especially with regard to energy costs. At a time when the Trump administration is threatening to cancel the Paris climate agreement and China continues to relentlessly pollute the environment, the European Union, as we saw in the previous debate, has decided to drastically reduce carbon emissions. This decision affects the competitiveness of the European economy. PPC is leading to financial failure. The entire Greek cement industry, which employs 13,000 people, is in danger of closing down and the Greek shipping industry is affected. I therefore tabled Amendment 162 in the previous debate and asked that Greece, under Article 10c of Directive 2003/87 / EC, be exempted from the obligations of the European Emissions Trading Scheme, because 2014 should be taken as the base year. , when Greece had a GDP of less than 60% of the Union. There can be virtually no competition policy when Greek industry and European industry are dissolved with all these notions of so-called environmental protection.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - Competitiveness is therefore one of the essential elements of the single market, but of course we must not neglect the important elements of this unity, especially in the field of working conditions and labor law. Because obviously competitiveness is also becoming one of the main generators of the so-called cross-cutting work, which puts many young people in despair and hopelessness. Then there is the issue of competitiveness, which is also being drafted by the European Commission, on so-called posting workers, which again calls into question, on the one hand, competition rules and, on the other, the protection of labor relations and, of course, social security. And we expect, of course, the Commission to sharply intervene in those elements where there are illegal cartels, monopolies, what my colleague has already pointed out. Above all, we expect a clear answer on Montsant and Bayer, and on other seed issues, because if that becomes ... (the President cut off the speaker) then Europe is in trouble.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the purpose of competition rules is to ensure a level playing field for businesses, regardless of their size or marketing capacity, to reach voters. For a long time, I have been asking various activities whether the expectations of consumers are met in the case of dual product quality, and also how their decision is determined by the brand, but under which the product is different. I therefore believe that the European Parliament will subscribe to a provision that repeatedly calls on the Commission to determine whether this practice has negative effects on local producers, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and whether it leads to discrimination between consumers as a result of supplying lower quality products. We first called on the Commission to conduct a proper inquiry four years ago. Even years later, the Commission itself is beginning to admit that double quality can be an unfair practice and therefore contrary to EU law. I therefore consider Amendment No 5 of the PPE Group, which calls into question the effects of dual quality on final consumers, to be completely unacceptable, and call for it to be rejected.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their very substantial comments. Unfortunately I will not be able to give each and every one an individual answer. One of the important things for me is for our rules to be an enabler. For instance, when Mr Schwab calls for tourism in state aid we will be more than happy to give guidance on where state aid is absolutely allowed, where it is no economic activity but allowing people to be acquainted with the region, to know what to do to find the businesses who do have the economic activity. That, I think, is the important thing. I also very much look forward to the debate with the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development because I think that we can meet one other to ensure jointly that we have a very competitive sector in which we use the means of competition and, at the same time, allow for a more balanced approach in sectors where many, many small suppliers are facing very heavy-duty negotiators on the other side of the table. I look forward to addressing these issues. Some of you have mentioned the tax issue. It is, of course, obvious that every Member State is sovereign in setting the level of their corporate taxation. If we want European tax legislation it will be through the front door, via the Council, with unanimity. In the same treaty that gives Member States the serenity to set their own tax level, we have very strong rules that say you cannot give a company, or group of companies, selective advantages. Selective advantages, paid for by taxpayers, ruin fair competition and, in particular, do not give small and medium-sized businesses a fair chance of making it in the market. Therefore, obviously, the Commission will also continue its work in relation to fiscal aid – a.k.a. tax and state aid. Some of you have been asking about the ongoing merger control procedures in two of three mergers in seeds and pesticides, or ‘crop protection’ as they call it. We will, of course, be as firm and as insistent as always to make sure that we have competition in this sector both for seeds and for pesticides. This is the very basis of our food chain and obviously we need competition there as well, and we will thoroughly investigate these mergers, including that of Bayer and Monsanto if we are finally notified of this. On the Google case, I very much appreciate the insistence, because these are important cases. We are dealing with fast-moving markets and, as was mentioned, we have companies which suffered while the investigation was ongoing. Therefore, we are doing our utmost to deal with the responses that we now have had to the statement of objection, and to examine them in detail to make sure that we give this company, like others, the right to defend itself, because that is important. As was mentioned, there is, of course, also a need for checks and balances when it comes to the Commission competences in enforcing competition law, and for the Court to be able to overrule our decisions. Therefore, our work should be thorough and expert, while, of course, speed is a very important challenge for us, precisely because, as was mentioned, these are fast-moving markets. Last but not least, we hope that the digital single market will not keep being mentioned as a separate part of the single market, but will come to be seen as a fully integrated part of the single market, because it offers a lot of choice for consumers. As you may know, we have opened three new cases in the field of digital business in order to make sure that every business has a fair chance of making it. These are in video games – part of the holiday business – and our aim is to make sure that consumers get the choice they should have. I will leave the detailed comments for now, but I assure you that we are using our best efforts to enforce competition law, and I very much take on board the things mentioned today – in particular by the rapporteur and in terms of the draft report’s recommendations for our future work.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, here again I must thank wholeheartedly the Commission and Commissioner Vestager, the shadow rapporteurs and of course those colleagues representing opinions in the various committees, for their contributions. Honestly, when we prepared this report it was not a fight, rather it was a spirit of cooperation which prevailed during the negotiations which means, for me at least, that common European policies do indeed have value.  But, looking at the practical nature of mankind, I think that competition is never fair. People do compete like this – look at the Olympics, or even just a simple football match where the referee needs to intervene hundreds of times during the same match – but the real question is, from the institutional point of view, what we do.  This is why I want to congratulate the Commissioner once again. She was not discouraged but stepped on such giants as Google, Uber, Bayer, Monsanto, Apple – I can give you a whole list. This courage is very much needed. On the other hand, I think that what we see now in Europe is really a bit frustrating: the big companies, or the bigger ones among them, are practically not paying tax due to various arrangements, but the small ones – sometimes they may die. So this is what we still have to consider.  I also very much welcome those comments related to agriculture because here price volatility simply kills. It is not just competition; it kills, it is lethal.  So once again, thank you very much for this opportunity, and again my wholehearted thanks to all the colleagues, and let us continue like this.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be take place on Tuesday, 14 February 2017.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on promoting gender equality in mental health and clinical research [2016/2096(INI)] (A8-0380/2016).

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: speaker. - Madam President, Commissioner Vestager, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs, their assistants and advisers from the political groups, because they have contributed to taking this report far beyond what it originally raised. It has been a great joint work in favor of equal rights. When we talk about gender inequality, we tend to think of the embarrassing salary gap, the ridiculous presence of women in decision-making positions or the great scourge that shames us: gender violence, whether physical or psychological. But we seldom think about how this inequality affects our daily life, our well-being, our health and especially our mental health. Did you know that biomedical research and clinical trials on drugs and treatments do not take into account that half of the population is women? That they do not take into account the biological, physiological and psychological differences between men and women, beyond their reproductive systems? I became aware of this problem some time ago when, on a visit to a hospital, a nurse told me about her experience. Hospital staff were concerned because she did not understand why many patients who had survived a heart attack returned to the hospital after a year and died shortly thereafter. The same hygienic conditions, the same monitoring mechanisms ... Medical histories, family precedents and other risk factors had been taken into account. But it took them time to realize that most of the patients who relapsed and died were women, because cardiovascular disease is more common in women than in men, and previous research lacked that approach. In mental health the problem is very well observed. There are considerable gender differences in patterns of mental illnesses, especially the most common ones: depression and anxiety, for example, mood disorders that any of us know firsthand, are almost three times more prevalent in women than in men. One in ten workers, for example, in the European Union has asked for a depression leave: that costs about 92 million euros a year. Mental health is also linked to employment and investment. The report we are discussing today fearlessly addresses these issues and others equally relevant, such as the devastating and lifelong effects that gender-based violence has on the mental health of victims, such as the prejudices that still exist against LGBTI people and that they condemn deteriorating mental health or as the urgent need to apply the guidelines on protection and support of the mental health and psychosocial well-being of refugees, asylum seekers and migrants in Europe. But when we talk about gender equality and health, it is imperative that we speak openly about abortion. Conscientious objection by physicians cannot endanger the health and freedom of a woman who requests a voluntary termination of pregnancy. It is simply unacceptable that in Italy, for example, more than 70% of doctors refuse to practice it today, despite being protected by law. We want to ensure that there is a minimum number of health professionals available to perform these medical interventions, which guarantee access to sexual and reproductive health services in all countries of the Union in accordance with current legal standards. The European Union is bound by its Treaties to guarantee the protection of human health as part of all its policies and to collaborate with the Member States to improve public health, prevent diseases and eliminate sources of danger to physical and mental health. In short: it is a legal and social responsibility of all political leaders to fully integrate the specific needs of women, half of the population, when defining public policies for health and services in the health sector at European and national level.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to apologize to my colleague, Mrs Basterrechea, because unfortunately I cannot support her report this time.I think there is more ideology than expertise in it.We should approach mental health care and clinical research from a purely medical and professional point of view and not from a gender ideology point of view.In addition, this report extends the concept to other irrelevant groups and, in particular, calls for the availability of abortion and recommends that Member States enforce abortion, regardless of the right of doctors and health professionals to make their own decisions.Unfortunately, this report is very unfortunate and I hope it will not be adopted.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, mental health and well—being are poorly understood in our societies and it is time for that to change. We actively need to break down the stigma and prejudice around mental well—being. Almost a third of Europeans will experience a mental health condition during their lifetime and we need to educate ourselves accordingly. It is clear that we need to take gender into account in mental health. Women are twice as likely to experience depression and anxiety as men as they face constant media objectification, as well as sexual violence and harassment. On the other hand, men and boys are also affected by gender stereotypes that often lead to repression of emotions. Men are three times more likely to commit suicide or develop alcohol and drug addictions.  This report is a strong call to the Commission and Member States to pursue an ambitious mental health and well—being strategy, which includes a psychosocial approach, taking into account the social, cultural and environmental factors that determine and affect mental health. It includes the impact of austerity policies, public service cuts, social inequalities, age and background. We need tailored policies to address the needs of the most vulnerable such as LGBTI women and women refugees.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, mental health in Europe is a vital topic and worthy of clinical research. But the rapporteur has produced a very bad report on this topic here. A large part of this report is based on fake gender ideological claims. It certainly is not scientific research; for example, recital O, which says that ‘whereas transgender identities are not pathological, but are deplorably still considered mental health disorders’, and that this is a diagnosis that causes distress to those receiving it. True scientific research should be carried out which is examined by specialists and not used for political ends. Politics should not dictate what changes are made in medical text books. Recital R refers to ‘gender-variant prepubescent children’. What are we doing confusing our children by encouraging them to choose their sex? This is a recipe for mental health problems. It is true that suicide is a huge problem among young men especially, but the cause is not the stereotyping of the two sexes. It is in fact the culture which confuses their God-given and natural capacities and nature.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, last Saturday the actions around the International Day of Women and Girls in Science highlighted a real thing: gender inequality in research.In other words, the universal pattern for research is the young, white male.That is why we Greens consider this report essential to reduce gender inequality.But, as a member, also, of the Development Committee, I would like to stress that we have to go further, from a north-south perspective.First, investment in global research and development is required to achieve universal health coverage.Second, we have to demand that transnational pharmaceutical companies respect human rights when conducting clinical trials.And third, we have to reduce poverty, guarantee access to education and social protection to end the gender gap in mental health once and for all.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, women whose mental health is impaired are facing stigma and a holistic approach is needed to help them.This report is far beyond the scope of both the topic and the competences of the European Union, and it interferes excessively with the profession itself.Healthcare and health policy are the responsibility of the Member States and we must respect that.We must not use that.This parliament should also not be used to promote a particular ideology contrary to the values of the European Union.A report that promotes abortion as socially acceptable and gender ideology as an ultimatum is absolutely unacceptable to me and I will not support it.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the honourable Members’ views on this interesting report, promoting gender equality in mental health and clinical research. I hope that we share the very fundamental principle of equality between men and women, which was established in the treaties as one of our most important goals. The Strategic Engagement for Gender Equality 2016-2019 is the Commission’s commitment to specific measures to promote gender equality. We are particularly grateful to this House for raising awareness of the differences between men and women in the prevalence and treatment of mental disorders and health in general. As you know, the health programme explicitly provides for the mainstreaming of gender equality in all actions promoted by the programme. Thus the Commission supported Member States’ cooperation on mental health with a Joint Action on Mental Health and Well-being under this programme. It resulted in a European Framework for Action on Mental Health and Well-being. This framework addresses gender differences, highlighting for example the different prevalence of depression between men and women. A recent call under the health programme invited proposals for projects on improving access to mental health care and mental health literacy. The Commission is also organising, on behalf of the Parliament, a pilot project to improve the understanding of sex and gender differences in chronic diseases, using coronary heart disease as one example. We fully agree with the resolution that mental health needs to be enshrined in a holistic patient-centred approach, for example addressing the impact of cancer and other major chronic diseases on patients’ mental health. In relation to research and innovation, we need to do more to address the gender dimension as reflected in Horizon 2020, the EU Research and Innovation Programme and, in particular, the work programme and the health—related calls for proposals. Over several EU research programmes the Commission has founded many research projects, specifically addressing diseases affecting women, such as breast cancer, osteoporosis and endometriosis. The Commission also founded several research projects under the Seventh Framework Programme with over EUR 5 million devoted to supporting endometriosis research, to which the report specifically refers. We must also continue our work to eradicate all forms of gender—based violence, including female genital mutilation. In addition, the new Clinical Trial Regulation, which will become applicable in 2018, provides that subjects participating in a clinical trial should represent a population group likely to be treated with the medical product under investigation in the trial. This includes gender, age, and, where relevant, subjects with specific needs. A further initiative that I would like to mention here is the Horizon 2020 Birth Day Prize that was launched in 2016. The Horizon Birth Day Prize will be awarded to a solution that best demonstrates a reduction in maternal or newborn morbidity and mortality or stillbirth during facility—based deliveries. Such a solution needs to be novel, safe and replicable because we need innovation here, as elsewhere. Finally, a word on the under-representation of women in health research. I readily acknowledge the significance of this issue. I understand, however, that the situation is now rapidly improving and I sincerely hope that this upward trend will continue. Thank you for giving me this opportunity to present the Commission’s approach to promoting gender equality, including regarding mental health and health issues in general. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 14 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – When we talk about gender equality, much of our focus is often directed at emancipating women in civil, political and economic society. And while much of the focus on the detrimental effects of patriarchal societies is targeted towards women, one serious issue targets men – the issue of suicide and mental health. If we raise our young men in societies where they are told that ‘boys don’t cry’, that they should be strong as opposed to weak, and stoic as opposed to emotive, then we will continue to perpetuate the stigmatisation of mental health. But while such ideals may be well intentioned, the phenomena has led to a major difference in suicide rates between men and women. In general, the rate for males is five times higher, and in some EU countries alone the differentiation between genders can lead to a figure of 52 males per 100 000 persons to 8 females per 100 000. This is a highly worrying phenomenon, and if even we as European leaders shy away from the topic, then we will continue to perpetuate the stigma within our own societies.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Constance Le Grip and Maria Arena on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, with a proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the EU priorities for the 61st session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women [2017/2001(INI)] (A8 008/2017).

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I am proud to be here today to give our priorities to the Council for the upcoming session of the United Nations Commission on the status of women. We cannot miss this opportunity to join forces and stand up together for women’s dignity worldwide, to combat stereotypes and any form of discrimination, going beyond rhetoric with concrete actions. Much more needs to be done everywhere to empower women and girls and achieve gender equality. We want to give a voice, especially to the millions of women that are excluded, marginalised, vulnerable women, women with disabilities, migrant and refugee women.  First of all we have to prevent and combat violence against women with a zero-tolerance policy to domestic violence, honour killings, trafficking, sexual abuse and exploitation, female genital mutilation, forced marriage. Let us face it, many women and girls are the new slaves of our times. Behind every victim there is a heartbreaking story of a broken life. We therefore call on the Member States to ratify and enforce the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention on violence against women. Second: education. We need to ensure access to school for all girls and keep them safe and empower them, then promote women in the labour market, in particular women’s entrepreneurship; recognise that women are an asset for our economy and growth; eliminate the gender-pay gap and ensure equal pay for equal work and more representation of women in decision-making everywhere. We need to work towards shared responsibility, a life and work balance between men and women in the care of children, and ensure that women and girls have universal access to health care, including sexual and reproductive health and rights. The UN Commission in March is an important opportunity for Europe to show the world that we are responsible and credible in women and girls’ rights.  We are at the crossroads. As the US seems to be retreating from global responsibility, Europe should step in. As the US seems to withdraw support for multilateralism, Europe should renew its support for the United Nations and international cooperation. As the US seems to be turning its back on women and girls’ health, Europe should show leadership in gender equality and women’s health.  We firmly condemn the recently reinstated global gag rule in its most extreme form yet, expanded to withdraw funding not only from reproductive health services but from an organisation’s entire health budget if they provide information about interruption of pregnancy. This will encompass all the United States’ global health funding from Africa through Asia to Latin America. There is an outcry, a chorus of concern turning to Europe for help, notably from the United Nations, other aid agencies, children’s rights NGOs, research institutes, foundations, charities. We Europeans are not going to abandon the thousands of women and girls depending on those donations.  I welcome the initiative of the Dutch Government to mobilise funds in order to compensate for the US funding and the Belgian initiative to hold a donors’ conference on 2 March. More countries and organisations should join the initiative to save the life of hundreds of thousands of women and girls in developing countries. The gag rule’s consequences are serious. They will affect many programmes: Zika virus, lifesaving services, pre-natal and post-natal assistance to babies and young mothers, women that are raped. It will increase mortality. More women and girls are going to die in birth and complications. I call on the UN and the Member States to give a clear, united response against this setback, sexism and Trumpism, and let us also support the women’s march and movement in the US.

name: Maria Arena
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, the Fourth World Conference on Women, held in Beijing in 1995, marked a real and important turning point in the global agenda for equality between women and men. The declaration and the program that had been adopted at the time - Program of Action for the Empowerment of Women - was considered to be the main global policy document on gender equality, there is over 20 years. The Beijing +20 session in 2015 welcomed the progress made in this area through this global instrument, but UN member states were nonetheless called on to carry out assessments and take further steps to accelerate the implementation. implementing these actions for equality. And yet, today, in 2017, we see that equality between men and women as well as the rights of women are again called into question. Around the world, policies aim to undermine the goals that should be supported not only by Europe but also by the United Nations in terms of equality between men and women. In response to these regressions, citizen resistance movements are organizing across the world. At the 61st session of the Commission on the Status of Women at the United Nations, we, the European Parliament, therefore ask that the Council can take the measure of its role within the international community to act in favor of equality between men and women, as it has always done at European level. This commitment, we ask that it go from the promotion of education to the fight against violence against women, and particularly to the adoption of the Istanbul Convention, through the guarantee of universal access to healthcare. sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights, as well as access to sexual and reproductive education. The participation of women in the labor market, without discrimination, as well as their participation in political and civic life are also essential for their empowerment. Dear colleagues, at the time of this 61st session, we can only condemn the attitude of the Trump administration, which has decided to cut funding to NGOs, as my colleague Corazza Bildt said, which practice or recommend family planning or access to abortion services, even in countries where abortion is accepted. This is a real violation of women's rights, which will have disastrous consequences for HIV programs, for the mental health we just mentioned, for the health of children. All of this will affect the whole world. Colleagues, we have had the opportunity to speak out and condemn the Trump administration when it promotes economic protectionism. When it comes to the economy, everyone stands up to say, "But what's going on in the United States?" On the other hand, when it comes to human rights and women's rights, we should be silent. No, Ladies and Gentlemen! Again, when it comes to human rights, we have to say that what this administration is doing today is not acceptable. We must say this to the United Nations and Europe must be at the forefront of this fight, quite simply because Europe must show that it is a pillar guaranteeing fundamental rights and that these fundamental rights - which are the rights of man - should not forget half of humanity that are women. Therefore, I urge you to support this proposal for a recommendation to the Council so that this image of Europe as the guarantor of fundamental rights can be brought to the world level.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the report also makes it clear that in no country are women fully guaranteed the means to economic independence, equal social representation and control over all decisions that affect their lives. I would add that in many cases the results achieved so far can even be reversed. That is why, in the current world political situation, when even the first person in the so-called democratic world speaks so often, publicly and vocally contemptuously about the better side of our society, it is especially important to be aware of these obstacles. Women, like other minorities or under-represented groups, deserve equality, fair treatment. And ensuring fair treatment requires concrete action. The Union must push for the abolition of discriminatory laws against women in UN member states. With a firm stand, we could also contribute to the development of the rule of law not only within the European Union but also outside it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, in 2017 no Member State has achieved equality between men and women. Gender equality is a fundamental right and a fundamental foundation for a peaceful, prosperous and sustainable world. Progress is slow and uneven. Significant gaps and forms of discrimination persist, despite well-founded indications that women's emancipation has made significant progress and has led to poverty reduction, growth promotion and challenge. In addition, women's entrepreneurship is an important economic factor on a global scale and the participation of women in the economic level contributes to the development of the economy and the creation of new jobs. But when an economy is hit, women are the first to be targeted. In Greece, the unemployment rate for women reaches 27.7%. Women are the group of the population that has been hit hardest by the austerity policy in Greece. The European Union must take steps to stop women from falling victim to stereotypes.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, there are people, amongst other places in the Oval Office, who want us to get tired, who want us to shut up and who want us to stop repeating the claim ‘Our bodies – our rights’. Well, here is to these people: we will not shut up, we will not get tired and we will not stop defending women's rights because they are fundamental rights. And the more that these people put pressure on us, the more we will unite not only here in this Parliament, but in the streets all over the world. And we will not only unite. We will demand concrete actions from our governments. They have to take responsibility. And that is why I demand that European governments join the initiative by the Dutch, the Danish, the Belgian and the Swedish governments in order to counter the impact of the global gag rule, because we will not get tired, we have only just begun.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, this report contains a number of good recommendations in terms of improving the status of women, their rights, economic independence and, last but not least, the fight against violence against women. Unfortunately, women are still victims of perhaps the most widespread form of human rights violations in the world, and we should also take this fact into account in asylum seekers. Experience from many parts of the world shows that women can play a significant role in settling conflicts and wars, and that their involvement in decision-making processes, even in the poorest countries, is often beneficial. On the contrary, what I cannot agree with in the report is the obligatory call for universal access to sexual and reproductive health to be guaranteed. Sadly, the report makes use of a factual mistake with regard to the Beijing platform. It only called for the fight against sexually transmitted diseases and greater awareness of women and a responsible approach to sexual issues.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, as a woman who works in an environment dominated by men, this topic is extremely close to me and I believe that we have a lot of work ahead of us in promoting equal legal protection for women and men. I believe that we need to make greater efforts to improve the position of women and to ensure that all girls and women have equal opportunities. Equal work must be paid equally, and barriers to women entering the labor market must be removed. I consider it important to encourage women to take up entrepreneurial activities, but I also call for support for women farmers, which is often neglected. Women are an essential link and foundation of society in every segment of it, which needs to be supported and legally protected as a standard, not as an exception. I also call for the rejection of amendments calling on the European Union to finance abortion with the money of our taxpayers around the world. This is not the task of the European Union and it is absolutely unacceptable. We will not improve the position of women with these measures, but by providing them with the same treatment as men.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up. - The European Union's goal of reducing poverty at European level is closely linked to greater involvement of women in the labor market. Promoting development at Union level cannot take place without the more active participation of women, who are important global economic agents. Countries that capitalize on and empower women to participate fully in the labor market and in decision-making processes are more stable, prosperous and more secure. I believe that joint efforts by the Union and the Member States are needed to encourage and support women's organizations at all levels in their professional activities, to involve them as partners in the policy-making process, and to ensure adequate funding. It is necessary to eliminate the pay gap between women and men, which then find themselves in the pension gap, to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women and gender stereotypes, which perpetuate inequality, violence and discrimination in all spheres of society.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Dennis de Jong on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on control of the Register and composition of the Commission’s expert groups [2015/2319(INI)] (A8-0002/2017).

name: Dennis de Jong
text: Reporter. - (NL) Mr President, we have seen how important a balanced composition of expert groups from the European Commission is in our investigation into the dieselgate affair. The high-level group Cars 21 consisted for the most part of representatives of the automotive industry. The Commission listened to them, but the warnings from environmental organizations against possible fraudulent software hardly got through to the offices of the same Commission. For years the European Parliament has been fighting against the dominance of the lobbyists of large companies in expert groups, but it was only after Parliament had frozen some of the funds intended for the expert groups that the Commission wanted to talk. I then had an informal dialogue with the Commission together with a group of like-minded MEPs. All that was during the previous mandate. After the European elections in 2014, there was an impasse. The Commission felt that we should just show which expert groups were unbalanced and then the Commission services would take action afterwards. That is of course the upside-down world. This is understandable when you consider that only one official was available at the secretariat of the Commission to supervise compliance with the then existing rules for expert groups. But it must of course be the Commission that detects possible wrongdoing. In the Committee on Budgetary Control we then decided to have our own research carried out. The results were not easy. The large companies still dominate in expert groups and they were not very transparent anyway. Minority views were not presented, nor was the course of the discussions. When discussing this investigation, it appeared that the Commission was already tightening up the rules. Good news in itself, of course, but it was a shame that there was no informal or formal consultation here had been over. After all, the Commission was fully aware of our intention to draw up a formal report with resolution on the expert groups. In the end we managed to adapt a sleeve here. I prepared a working document and the Commission services responded in writing. A few points of difference remained, which we subsequently discussed informally with Vice President Timmermans. That conversation went well, but unfortunately many points were not included in the new rules and hence this report. The main requirements we have are: One: clear criteria for the expertise the Commission is looking for. Two: definition of which interests according to the Committee should be represented in the specific expert group and what a balanced balance is between those interests. Three: a good system to handle complaints about the criteria and the definition of “balanced balance” among individual expert groups. Four: not only reimbursement of travel and accommodation costs, but also of opportunity costs. Think of an SME who has to incur costs to keep her business open when she herself participates in an expert group. Five: opening up expert groups of national NGOs, so that they also receive the mandate of a European umbrella organization. Six: unless a qualified majority of the members of the expert group objects to this, disclosure of agendas, background papers and minutes with clear guidelines on how detailed we should be. Seven: Avoiding conflicts of interest among participants on behalf of the academic institution, law firm, or think tank. And finally: sufficient staff to supervise compliance with the rules. I sincerely hope that after the unanimous acceptance of this report in the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Commission will become somewhat more proactive. That is why we ask the Commission to report on the operation of the new rules before 1 July. A commission that says transparency should not allow pushing and pulling.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, the lack of transparency and the unbalanced composition of many expert groups in the Commission make it necessary to control the Register and the composition of these groups. As the lack of transparency has a negative effect on the confidence of the citizens of the Member States of the Union in its institutions, the effective reform of the Commission's expert system should be based on the principles of transparency and balanced composition. As early as May 30, 2016, the Commission had adopted horizontal rules on the establishment and operation of expert groups, in order to make public calls for applications for the selection of members of these groups and thus increase transparency. Finally, the Register of Expert Groups should aim to further increase the transparency of these expert groups and to clarify ways in which under-represented social group organizations can be really encouraged to participate in expert groups.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, tomorrow at this point we will look at the future of the European Union.When I read those proposals looking for a way out of the current structural crisis, it occurred to me that we were once again completely forgetting those for whom the European project is to serve, our citizens.All too often, the EU is tackling problems through force and closing in on itself, and we, as elected representatives, must call on the Commission to act transparently and responsibly towards EU citizens in the document under discussion.How is it that this is not at the very core of the Commission's functioning?We blame the Commission for not having a proper public consultation, and we must reiterate the importance of revitalizing the various forms of involvement of civil society representatives and the social partners.If the Commission were able to take these small steps, we would not have to debate the big ones tomorrow.Even so, I thank my colleague for the prepared report.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr de Jong, for his report and work on this very important topic. I think it is a thing that we share, that these rules are of the essence for the legitimacy of the advisory and expert groups. This Commission has paid very close attention to the role which expert groups play in our policy making. And we have laid down tougher internal rules in order to make sure that these groups carry out their function in full transparency and accountability exactly as asked. Let me stress just one thing, because this is very basic. Expert groups provide very useful contributions to the work of the Commission in many different policy fields, of which many are highly technical and of a specialised nature. But I think it is very important to recall that no matter what advice is given by expert groups, they have a purely advisory role. Whatever their advice may be, the responsibility for any decision or measure adopted remains the Commission’s and the Commission's alone. But when this Commission took office we decided that the rules for expert groups needed to be reviewed so as to better reflect the Commission's commitment to be more transparent and accountable. Before adopting a new set of rules, we listened to this Parliament, the European Ombudsman and civil society organisations. After a full year of consultation and intensive preparation the Commission adopted new rules in May last year. We consider these new rules, which are binding for all of the Commission services, to improve significantly the management, the balance and the transparency of expert groups and we also consider that they provide a positive response to many suggestions made by this House and by the European Ombudsman. Just let me give you a few concrete examples.  The new rules confirm – reconfirm – the Commission's commitment to strive for a balanced composition of expert groups. The Commission’s departments must do their utmost to guarantee a balanced representation. This does not mean balanced in a mathematical sense, which would be difficult to define and achieve in all cases; it means maximum balance in terms of expertise, interests, gender, and geographical origin. The new rules also bring significant changes to boost transparency. We have set up a new register for expert groups. This register is accessible for the public and provides more accurate information and more documents drafted and discussed by expert groups. In particular, the Commission will henceforth publish the register calls for applications when it selects stakeholders’ representatives as well as expert group members appointed in their personal capacity. This is a major step forward and has been a long-standing request from this Parliament. In other words, we have made the selection procedures fully transparent and inclusive, which ultimately benefits the balance of the composition of expert groups. Second, registration in the Transparency Register has now become a precondition for stakeholders’ organisations to be appointed to an expert group. This means that where particular interests are represented in an expert group there will be full transparency as regards the nature of these interests. Third, every document that an expert group produces must now be put on the register of expert groups. Minutes will have to be provided, which makes complete and meaningful sense. Moreover, expert groups can also decide to open up their meetings to the general public. Last but not least, we have taken tough measures to avoid conflict of interest in expert groups. Under the new rules, independent experts can only be appointed on the basis of standardised and detailed conflict-of-interest assessment based on the declaration submitted by these experts. Only if the Commission services conclude that there is no conflict of interest may those experts be appointed in their personal capacity. In addition, all declarations of interest of independent experts are published in the register of expert groups. These tougher rules we have put in place to ensure – and I do hope that you find that we, the Commission and this House, share the objective – a high degree of transparency and accountability for the functioning of expert groups. The Commission is committed to rigorously applying our new rules and we know of course that you will scrutinise us closely and we remain of course open to continuing the dialogue with this Parliament as to how to improve and how to make sure that we follow closely this important matter.
