name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Dennis de Jong on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the role of whistle-blowers in the protection of EU’s financial interests [2016/2055(INI)] (A8-0004/2017).

name: Dennis de Jong
text: Reporter. - (NL) Mr President, in the media we sometimes see images of empty port areas or airports without air traffic, financed by the European Union, or rocky areas for which subsidies are provided in the context of rural development. Investigative journalists do a good job of discovering and reporting such wrongdoing. It also regularly happens that concerned members of the Committee on Budgetary Control receive letters from citizens about cases of alleged fraud and corruption involving European funds. And often they put a name under the letter with all the details so that they can be contacted. Investigative journalists and concerned citizens are taking risks. In the European Union, we have regulated the protection of trade secrets, but not the protection of whistleblowers. The anti-fraud service of the European Commission has a protocol on how to deal with whistleblowers and most European institutions now also have implementing rules for internal staff to protect them when they report abuse. But beyond that, you depend on the goodwill of the officials or politicians who receive your information. Someone recently responded: “Surely the citizen who wrote to us is not asking for confidential treatment at all? Then why should we not be able to mention his name? ” We do not know at all how it is regulated in the Member States. Even if we have good rules in the European institutions, whistleblowers can still be sued at national level. Just think of the fate of the whistleblowers who have to go to court in connection with Luxleaks in Luxembourg, when their sole aim was to denounce tax avoidance by multinationals and Luxembourg's role in it. My report contains a large number of proposals to protect whistleblowers finally organizing properly. Better procedures within the European institutions themselves, counters with people who know how to handle information from whistleblowers and who safeguard the confidentiality of personal data. Whistleblowers are also entitled to advice. In the Netherlands we have set up a house for whistleblowers for this purpose, and an initial investigation is being carried out there into the information that whistleblowers provide. Whistleblowers then receive advice on how to proceed. Such a house is just as badly needed on a European level. You soon become entangled in the forest of the European institutions and before you know it, it is not the abuses that are dealt with, but you yourself. Of course, the European Parliament can take steps itself. In theory, we could set up such a house for the whistleblowers themselves. But it is much better to have one house for all European institutions. It is fine and even necessary that information about wrongdoing reaches Parliament, but the European Commission and the agencies can also benefit from that information. And let us not forget the important role of the European Court of Auditors and the European Ombudsman. Article 325 of the EU Treaty provides a good legal basis for the regulation of protection at national level. Precisely by concentrating first on whistleblowers who report wrongdoing in which the financial interests of the European Union are at stake, I believe we meet all subsidiarity requirements. Surely no one can be against protecting people who stick their necks out to report wrongdoing with our tax money? In that case, it is important that we make legislation that, while preventing abuse, really protects anyone who has a reasonable suspicion about the accuracy of his or her information. There is a lot of work for the Commission here. I would point out again that my report was adopted without a single vote against or abstention. So clear The Commission cannot ignore this signal.And I count on fast and good initiatives.Actions rather than words.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, protecting whistleblowers who risk their careers is in the general interest of society, both at European Union and Member State level.I therefore agree with the call in this report, which proposes and recommends that Member States address legislation at national level that would protect whistleblowers.The question is what the report also states whether a new independent European body should be set up to protect whistleblowers.I believe that it is premature to use the institutions we already have at European level, such as OLAF.In any case, this is a very complex area of legislation, where it is necessary to find a balance between the protection of workers who are not afraid to stand up to their superiors, but at the same time take into account that there may be notices that are false.In any case, it is a good initiative and I will be voting in favor of this report.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against corruption and fraud is and must increasingly be a central theme of the EU's political action, which must equip itself with adequate measures and tools to allow for particularly complex investigations such as those relating to them normally to cases of corruption and financial fraud to the detriment of the Union. An important resource in this sense are whistleblowers, whose contribution - we heard from my colleague de Jong - has brought to light cases of conflicts of interest, tax evasion and avoidance, money laundering and also infiltration of organized crime to the detriment of financial interests Union. It is therefore desirable that the Commission presents as soon as possible a legislative proposal aimed at guaranteeing the protection of whistleblowers according to common standards in all Member States and creating safe channels for reporting irregularities, which allow confidentiality and sharing of information, while ensuring adequate assistance to the informant.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, complainants play an important role in preventing, detecting and reporting irregularities and irregularities in connection with expenditure related to the Union budget, as well as in detecting and disclosing cases of corruption. For this reason, they should be protected by the Union, as set out in the latest report on the European Ombudsman, of which I was the rapporteur, and which explicitly mentions the need to protect complainants. To date, however, most Member States of the Union have failed to provide adequate legal protection to complainants, thus weakening an important anti-corruption tool. The protection of complainants and journalists should therefore be legally guaranteed and strengthened throughout the European Union, as long as their action is aimed at protecting the public interest. Finally, another ethics and ethics mentality needs to be consolidated to ensure that complainants are not retaliated against.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: –  Madam President, I would like to thank Dennis de Jong for the outstanding work with the report. I would like to welcome the European Parliament’s calls for a horizontal instrument for the protection of whistle-blowers yet again and unanimously in the Committee on Budgetary Control and I hope the same for the plenary. I hope the report fits into also the Commission’s ongoing work on assessing the possibility for action, as this is clearly a common European interest to have an overall protection for whistle-blowers. Horizontal protection is the only way to ensure that all those who report wrongdoings in the interest of the public do not suffer from any sort of retaliation. I believe that it is not only a moral obligation for the EU to act in a context where citizens’ trust in the institutions is low and the perception of corruption is high. It is also indispensable to ensure that EU law is properly implemented in wide areas from the protection of the financial interests of the European Union to the environmental acquis. I hope the plenary will vote for this report and the Commission is going to act.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr de Jong, and ask the Commissioner - who I know is also particularly sensitive to these issues - that, just as we have records of lobbyists and also the Code of Conduct for Commissioners - who could be improved, but who have served as an example and guide for the Member States that are further behind - we also need a code that protects and gives legal framework to whistleblowers at European level, which would be the mark and guide so that, at national levels - for example in my country, where they exist and where they are experiencing real hardships and very, very conflictive situations - we could at least serve as a guide to give them that protection. Therefore: legal framework, of course, for these complainants, with their rights and obligations as well. But, above all, a legal framework that would give them protection when they enter a kind of limbo in which they lose their jobs, they are in a truly terrible psychological situation ... And, of course, all the help to the There is no way to thank them for the common good and the common interest they are carrying out, and they must be protected. Please, Commissioner, help us with this.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, whistleblowers could indeed play a key role in helping Member States and EU institutions. Unfortunately, this is probably only a theoretical possibility, at least in Hungary, where the main function of state institutions is to convert public money into private money. State corruption defines people’s daily lives to such an extent that someone may lose their job even if they respond positively to a critical post against the government on the social media interface. Similarly, NGOs are under constant pressure, as there is a criticism of the Orbán government and they are already stamping the stamps of foreign agents. In such an environment, it is very difficult to convince people that reporting abuses is essential for the public good and for protecting the European Union's financial interests. What a public interest announcer can expect in Hungary today is the loss of its existence and its dragging on the public service media.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, first off I just want to congratulate Dennis de Jong on this report. A legal framework for whistle-blowers is essential. At the moment, if you are going to become a whistle-blower in a financial sense it is a toss-up between whether you are crazy or whether you actually really want to change things, and it should be the latter. You should not have to be crazy to do it but at the moment, if you look at the evidence, that is the case. You look at people like Jonathan Sugarman who tried to blow the whistle on UniCredit in Ireland for breaches in liquidity. What happened to him? He never worked again. He has not worked to this day. So unless things change the message is very, very clear. If you blow the whistle and if you blow the whistle strong, it will most likely be rammed down your throat and the total and utter goal is to stop you ever talking again. So we need this to change because unless we do we will have anarchy and we will have even more scepticism and I do not think you want that.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as is quite obvious and as you all have underlined, whistle-blowers help to uncover threats or harm to our public interest. They play an extremely important role in fighting fraud and corruption. According to a study from 2016 analysing more than 2400 cases of fraud in 114 countries, about 40% of all detected fraud cases are uncovered by whistle-blowers.  The Commission therefore strongly supports the objective of protecting whistle-blowers and this is why specific guidelines were developed back in 2012. This is also why it has been included in protective measures in the European legislation on anti-money laundering, market abuse, collective investment in transferable securities and trade secrets.  Recent leaks, such as the Panama papers, have once again highlighted the importance of whistle-blowers for journalistic investigations and, in this particular case, for exposing tax avoidance and tax evasion. Strengthening the fight against tax evasion, avoidance and illicit financial activity, promoting good tax governance, is one of the Commission’s top priorities, as you all know. The Commission is currently assessing the need for horizontal or further sectoral action at EU level, with full respect for the principle of subsidiarity. We are carrying out an impact assessment study and a public consultation will be launched at the end of February. Both will inform our assessment of the next possible steps. I count on your support to encourage a wide range of citizens and stakeholders to support and participate in this consultation.  We all agree that the protection of whistle-blowers is vital. The question is how best to achieve this objective and how we can contribute at the European level and in the European part of our democracy. A lot has already been done in fields where the European Union has competence. We now need carefully to assess the needs and the possible scope for horizontal or further sectoral action here in the European democracy to see what we can do at a European level while fully respecting the principle of subsidiarity.  I look forward to continuing and deepening the discussion with you on this subject.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 14 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The role of whistleblowers for the defense of legality and therefore also for the protection of the financial interests of the Union is absolutely central.The guarantee of protection for those who provide information in this sense must therefore be absolute;the protection in this sense must also extend to the economic aspects, because it is easy for informants to lose their jobs following their informations.The level of protection of these people varies greatly from state to state and it is therefore necessary to introduce European minimum standards in this regard.We are therefore committed to requesting a timely response from the Commission, to producing a legislative proposal to that effect.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The protection of whistleblowers is important for the European Union. It is a necessary step in the fight against corruption, the disclosure of conflicts of interest or any concealment of similar facts. Such people must be provided with assistance and protection against any retaliation. It also means avoiding coercion, questioning, or even criminalizing them. This is true even if they are wrong. Through their actions, they draw attention to the abuse of powers and, ultimately, help to preserve the credibility of the institutions at both national and European level. The lawfulness of the use of European funds is primarily to be ensured by the Member States as recipients. Of course, close cooperation with the European Anti-Fraud Office is also needed. In addition, they have a variety of tools at their disposal. However, the results within individual countries are often unsatisfactory

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: signed up.- I support the launch of a legislative proposal to establish a European whistleblower protection program, in order to impose a series of measures to simplify the process of exposing the misuse of European Union money.This involves setting up an advisory body with offices in the Member States, as well as setting up a website where complaints can be lodged.Pending the establishment of an independent European body, the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) will have to publish an annual report on the assessment of whistleblower protection in the European Union.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing. - Strengthening the protection of the European Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud, which are among the most important elements of the EU's political agenda, play a huge role in increasing citizens' trust in the EU institutions. Both the Commission and the Member States should give absolute priority to the fight against fraud and protect those who contribute to the effective fight against irregularities. In many Member States, there is only partial whistleblower protection through provisions in different laws, which means no separate law and thus no whistleblower protection practice. As a consequence, it significantly reduces the possibility of effectively combating fraud and corruption. That is why it is so important to create mechanisms to protect whistleblowers in the European Union, inter alia, by establishing an independent institution with the task of providing advice, information and assistance to such persons. To be fully effective, the whistleblower protection mechanism should also extend to businesses, public authorities and non-profit organizations. It should also protect whistleblowers who are exposed to retaliation by the institution where the irregularities take place. Each Member State should ensure that EU and international standards and guidelines on whistleblower protection are correctly implemented in their national law. Only this form of combat will allow full-scale protection of whistleblowers, who increasingly contribute to a more effective fight against irregularities.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: written. - Systematic abuses in different organizations can only come to light if someone intervenes from within. The whistleblower often takes a big personal risk. At the moment, the situation is miserable, as a company that has acted improperly or even criminally often receives more protection than the person who reported the abuse. It is important to be able to provide the notifier with legal protection that allows the notifier to take the risk. Often, a whistleblower faces a lot of pressure and suffers from financial insecurity, psychophysical symptoms, and many other factors that interfere with a normal life. We should create a safety net through legislation that allows risks to be taken. In this way, abuses would be better publicized, which is in the interest of society as a whole. The fact that many notifiers now wish to remain anonymous shows that their level of protection is still far from satisfactory.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the recent events in Ukraine are a matter of serious concern. While the number of casualties has risen in the east of the country due to renewed fighting and innocent civilians have become grounded, while part of the political elite is stirring up new conflicts instead of remedying real problems, it is working to discriminate on the rights of nationalities. The education bill disadvantages the languages ​​of national minorities, the current language law has been challenged in the Supreme Court, and the submitted language bills would ban the free use of national languages ​​in the public, private and civil spheres. These measures seriously violate the constitutional rights of indigenous national and linguistic minorities in Ukraine and are also contrary to the country's international obligations. The European Union needs a stable and strong Ukraine, but that requires real change. To this end, the EU should also closely monitor developments in Ukraine and respect for fundamental human rights. In a country striving for European integration, the curtailment of democratic rights is unacceptable, as it hinders the peaceful consolidation of the country.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I strongly condemn the call of the Prime Minister of the Belgian region of Wallonia, Paul Maniet, for Bulgaria's withdrawal from the European Union. I consider such chauvinistic statements unacceptable, especially since Mr Maniett and I belong to the same political family. In turn, I advise him to stop cheaply flirting with the Belgian electorate and to think about how we can build a Europe of solidarity and oppose the populist rhetoric of far-right political formations. I admire Mr Maniet's position on the trade agreement with Canada (SETA), but I strongly oppose his attempts to treat Bulgarians as second-hand citizens in the European Union. Moreover, we have a history of over 1300 years. We do not need a new Nigel Farage in Europe, especially among the ranks of the Socialists.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The death of a young woman due to thromboembolism following the use of third-generation hormonal contraceptives, recently reported in the British press, should also serve as a warning here - similar to the thousands of complications after using contraceptive pills - not only for women but for all who defend their rights to insulating. Women are now addicted to hormones from an early age, ranging from acne treatment, followed by hormonal contraception, which results in severe cycle disorders, subsequent miscarriages, various types of cancer, also at an early age, cardiovascular diseases, to ovarian failure after the age of thirty-five. life that requires the use of an equally dangerous hormone replacement therapy. The only tangible benefits of such hormone therapies come from the wealthy pharmaceutical companies and, of course, the in vitro promoters.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Bosnia and Herzegovina suffers from nationalism, which has been escalating recently. But that country is not getting any adequate help to fight that nationalism. Just look at how some parliamentarians here are talking about the federalization of the country in these separatist and nationalist times. Thus, in a country with fourteen parliaments, three presidents, 130 ministers, further fragmentation is proposed. As "that's the solution." The country doesn’t work with 14 parliaments so let’s try with 30, maybe it works. I'm sorry, but that's nonsense. Bosnia's problem is that nationalist policies have been operating with impunity for the past 20 years. Although there are means and the possibility to stop it. And after 20 years, of course, for some to start thinking "why don't we pursue the same policy, it obviously pays off". If Europe really wants to reduce nationalism, the creation of a functioning state should be promoted. Forget federalization, divisions, entities, nonsense. Let's help the country become a functional and legal state, then all that will sort itself out.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, last week (First) Vice-President Timmermans quietly shelved his anti-corruption reports, saying that there is no need for any more reports on Member States. However, in Ireland this week we have learned that there has been a vile, sinister and concerted campaign to destroy the character and private life of a Garda police whistle-blower. The whistle-blower, Maurice McCabe, raised  concerns about Garda malpractice, but his complaints were not processed: instead he was vilified by his own police force and on Thursday it was disclosed that he was the victim of a false accusation of child abuse. A full public inquiry needs to ascertain whether there was collusion between government and the police force to destroy the character of Maurice McCabe.  What the McCabes and the Irish public need to know now is who and what knew of this allegation. Was the Garda Commissioner involved in the smear campaign and were there present or former members of the Irish Government who were aware of the heinous false allegations? The time for cover-ups and black propaganda is over, but the fight against corruption is far from over, Vice-President Timmermans.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, a few years ago, Parliament approved the establishment of Frontex, the purpose of which was to assist Member States in border protection, coordinating border protection and coordinating the return and repatriation of illegal migrants.When I found out from the media that this agency was doing the exact opposite, that instead of helping to protect the European Union's borders from illegal migration, it was going to the shores of Africa, hunting migrants there and transporting them to Europe., I interpellated the Commission on how this is possible.Isn't this an excess of official authority?Isn't this the misuse of taxpayers' money?Doesn't that threaten the security of the European Union, of all Europeans?I think so, and I do not understand that the European Commission has not responded to my interpellation for six months.He responds very quickly.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF).
text: - Madam President, as you know, the social and political situation in Romania is tense due to some controversial normative acts that the government wanted to adopt with suspicious haste and some street demonstrations generated by this situation. Unfortunately, the legitimate dissatisfaction of the citizens has been politically diverted. After the repeal of that ordinance, the street demonstrations continue exactly in the sense explicitly indicated by the President of Romania. I emphasize that, in accordance with the Romanian Constitution, the president must be a mediator. Only two months after the free and fair parliamentary elections, prolonging the demonstrations, beyond achieving the original goal, is a risk to democracy. Basically, the precedent was set for any active and vocal minority in the street to be able to block not only one measure of an institution but the entire institution. It has gone from criminalizing a deed to criminalizing a political election. It is worrying that the demonstrations in Bucharest are widely presented on many European media channels as an example that Romania gives to European countries. What is not retained in the Western media is the discourse of hatred in the street, beyond the correct political content of banners written in English, the chants of Democrats incite physical violence on some people or on the sympathizer of a political platform.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Hungarians in Transylvania sympathize and hold together with their fellow citizens protesting against corruption and the Romanian government seeking to legalize corruption. That is why we are shocked to note that leading government politicians - in connection with the recent meeting between Vladimir Putin and Viktor Orbán - mention “external intervention” and “Hungarian revisionism” in the background of hundreds of thousands of demonstrations. The appeal of the nearly one hundred members of the Romanian Academy of Sciences wants to protect the identity, sovereignty and national unity of the country directly from the Szekler-Hungarian territorial autonomy. The Romanians and the Hungarians of Transylvania fought together against the communist dictatorship in 1989 as well. After twenty-seven years, we are also acting together against the corrupt post-communist regime. We protest against the false nationalist propaganda that tries to deceive the majority Romanian with the non-existent Hungarian threat. Romania must be protected not from Hungarians and not from autonomy, but from corruption!

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I have already raised a couple of times here the issue of the clients of IronFX – a Cyprus based foreign-exchange company that continuously swallows small investors’ deposits by simply denying their withdrawal requests. The crime has been going on for two years already and still there is no sign of any intervention, either by the Cypriot authorities or by those of the European Union. It is a shame, but the EU is merely deaf and silent. However, it is not only certain financial companies that swallow people’s money in Europe – the Hungarian Government also behaves as a kind of black hole in terms of European development aid to Hungary. Practically all these amounts are diverted into the pockets of proxies or family members, leaving little space, if any, for transparency. No wonder then that media are asserting more frequently that Orbán and his team may also be subject to Russian bribery. Indeed, the Hungarian Prime Minister shamelessly acts in the interests of Mr Putin and against European achievements. The EU, and especially the Commission, cannot be blind or silent any longer.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President!Justice Commissioner Vera Jourová spoke in favor of applying budget sanctions to Poland if our country does not accept the European prosecutor's office.I appeal to the President of the European Commission to clearly distance himself from these words and to turn to Mrs Vera Jourova - pursuant to Art.17 of the Treaty on European Union - to resign from the seat in the European Commission.The declaration of the Commissioner is a very demonstrative manifestation of the tendency to force the imperial authority of the institutions of the European Union against the countries of Europe, against their law, against our common treaty law and against the will of the nations.Members of the House!This tendency, in its consequences, affects not only my country and individual countries of the European Union, but also the European cooperation itself and the Union itself, because such actions only deepen the chaos and crisis on our continent.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, last week the Irish Prime Minister met the Polish Prime Minister and on the agenda was the push by Ireland for special status in the Brexit negotiations. The Polish Prime Minister was non-committal and said it was one of many questions that needed to be addressed, and yes, it is – but it is a very crucial question.  Ireland does not look for special status because we are Ireland, but because there are special circumstances, very special circumstances. Our exports to the UK are about 17% of our total exports, much higher than any other Member State, and 41% of those exports are in the agri-food sector, leaving it open to catastrophic impacts in the event of a hard Brexit. Our land border stretches 499 kilometres from west to east. We have strong cultural, social, economic ties with Northern Ireland, and our peace process is underpinned by cross-border cooperation in all sectors. A hard border would bring about huge dislocation in all these areas. Our job as MEPs is to ensure this reality is heard and taken on board by our partners.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the last issue of Portuguese debt ten years ago was made at interest rates above 4%. Eurogroup threats have returned. It is demonstrated that it is impossible to defend Portugal's interests without facing the issue of debt and the euro. It is illusory to expect that deficit fulfillment or subordination to the debt burden will result in some kind of mercy on the part of the markets and their political representatives. If we exclude interest on the debt, Portugal has a primary budget balance of more than 4 billion euros. Devoid of monetary sovereignty, the euro's periphery is totally dependent on the options of the ECB, which it does not control, or on the blackmail of rating agencies. In other words, the euro has stuck the periphery between the blackmail of the troika and the blackmail of the financial markets. And the solution is not to yield to any of them, it is to recover monetary sovereignty and exit the euro from Member States that consider their permanence unsustainable, as well as renegotiating debt, terms, interest and amounts, preferably in the framework negotiated at European level.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Madam President, the European Union does not have a coherent trade policy towards China. On January 27, the Commission decided, under pressure from the National Front, to subject the import of Chinese steel to a surcharge of over 30%. This retaliatory measure aims to save what remains of the European steel industry. It is, alas, too late for Florange, whose blast furnaces were stopped because of the Chinese dumping that the ultraliberal dogma of Brussels allowed to flourish. This dogma, the Commission has by no means renounced, because it has just announced the end of the import surcharges on Chinese solar panels. This corresponds to Merkel's desire to develop free trade with China. Ultimately, the Union only seeks to deceive the peoples of Europe. She only taxes Chinese steel the better to divert their attention from the surrender she is about to sign in all other areas.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: - More than ever, after 60 years of European integration, we need a decision on a solid Europe.We must first agree on what we want at all, whether we will be defending a strong Europe, a Europe built on European values.Because we are aware that a healthy economy is key to maintaining the European social model, and where rights go hand in hand with responsibility.Tomorrow we will discuss the future of the European Union.Let me say that eminent Slovenian lawyers have submitted a new draft of the European Constitution, which is based on the belief that the European Union can only be a balanced union of nation states, their civil societies and market economies with mutual respect.I am glad that the initiative came from my country, Slovenia, which is one of the smallest members.Not all of the proposed solutions may be acceptable to all, but, colleagues, I invite you to read on.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, last week’s vote on the Article 50 bill in the UK paved the way for a dangerous hard Tory Brexit. At this point in history, we have a responsibility to speak truth to power and take a moral stand. Contrary to Mrs May’s dangerous and dogmatic spin, Brexit will not be a success for ordinary people and its consequences will be profound and far-reaching, affecting our global geopolitical position, as well as local communities. I recently visited Calderwood House hostel for the homeless in Cumbria and met men and women, including ex-military personnel, whose lives are being transformed thanks in part to European funding which kick-started this social enterprise. An ERDF business development grant of GBP 1 000 has resulted in entrepreneur Rachel Holliday raising more than half a million pounds to renovate a disused building and establish a coffee retail service run by the hostel residents. This is not charity but the homeless helping themselves, and in doing so, lessening the burden on the state. Without EU funding will we have this kind of enterprise in the future?

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the Spanish Nuclear Safety Council has approved a report in favor of the reopening of the oldest and smallest nuclear power plant in that State, that of Santa María de Garoña. The report acknowledges that the plant has not implemented the mandatory security improvements after the Fukushima disaster. Nor have the transparency obligations established by the Directive on nuclear safety been fulfilled, as denounced here by the president of the Álava County Council, which seriously compromises the safety of citizens living in the area of ​​influence in the event of a possible accident. The Commission has also not received the investment plans for the plant, which is in full violation of the Euratom Treaty. You cannot accumulate more non-compliances or more reasons for distrust in the face of a plant that, due to its capacity and conditions, is not necessary to guarantee the electricity supply. The European Union has obligations and arguments to join the institutions and citizens in their resounding "no" to this incomprehensible decision.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, conventional wisdom has it that when there is a breakdown of law and order it is due to external forces. In Ireland, at the moment, law and order is in crisis but it is a crisis that comes from within. The country is convulsed and repulsed at the treatment of a police officer, a whistle-blower, Sergeant Maurice McCabe, an incredibly courageous individual who for his courage has been demonised in the most vile terms by some of the most senior echelons of the force, with a former press officer stating that he was instructed to spread lies and innuendo about Sergeant McCabe. Then there is the Jobstown scandal. Deliberately and provocatively a government minister visited an area her government policies had helped to devastate. Her car was blocked by a sit-down protest but only her car. When she decided to leave, she did so unmolested and unharmed. As a result of this 19 people were arrested, a 15-year-old boy already found guilty and a former MEP up in court shortly, Paul Murphy. I stand with Paul Murphy and the other Jobstown protesters. So should every person in this House who believes in fairness.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Dear Colleagues, I have repeatedly confronted this House, the European Commission and the Government of Portugal with the daily risks that the Almaraz nuclear power plant represents for Portugal, a few kilometers from Portugal and the Tagus River. Almaraz is an obsolete plant, an authentic time bomb that should have closed in 2010, but which saw its life extended until 2020. The Portuguese, 40 years ago, in Ferrel, were massively opposed to the construction of a nuclear plant in their territory, as well as to the nuclear projects that Spain has been carrying out over our territory, in violation of the international obligations to which it is bound. The licensing of the temporary warehouse in Almaraz, due to its enormous storage capacity, clearly demonstrates Spain's camouflaged intention to collect not only Almaraz waste after 2018, but also that of the other six Spanish nuclear power plants. It also demonstrates the willingness to extend the operation of Almaraz until the age of sixty, as it happened last week with the decision to reopen the Garoña nuclear power plant, which is sixty years old. Dear Colleagues, we cannot allow the Portuguese to continue to live in permanent shock. Portugal cannot become Spain's nuclear dump.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, biodiversity, the result of billions of years of evolution shaped more and more not by natural processes but by anthropogenic actions, is the subject of many debates and conferences, legislation, speeches and written works. About the effects of anthropogenic on natural systems, respectively on the slow degradation of ecological systems threatened even extinction, there are many arguments, economic, ethical, scientific, aesthetic, approaches and possible solutions, combating droughts and floods, protecting species, recycling , climate stabilization, etc. But one of the concepts of biodiversity refers to the ethnocultural diversity of socio-economic systems, diversity currently facing increasing pressure under the impact of anthropogenic action, which makes them work more and more inefficiently, the main causes being the inability of the population to appreciate the long-term consequences of human activities, the inability of markets to recognize the value of human capital, decision-makers to use human capital skills and others, the effects being visible physically and virtually but with profound consequences for the existence of the material world and human well-being.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I want to bring here today the situation of shellfish gatherers and shellfish gatherers in the Galician estuaries who see how the frequent events in the areas where they work - the death of shellfish, the cause of the contamination of water and accumulated mud - threaten their jobs. The sources of pollution are diverse: the pulp company in Pontevedra, the San Finx mine in Lousame, but also the malfunctioning of wastewater purifiers or that the necessary cleaning and sanitation projects are not carried out. The rivers in the villages of Ferrol, Noya or Pontevedra are just a few examples. We call the attention of the European Commission to oblige the Galician authorities and those of the Spanish State to put in place all the measures that are necessary to remedy this situation and to carry out, once and for all, the sanitation and rationalization of the Galician rias and so that urban wastewater is properly collected and treated. The economic penalty is not enough, it is the people who pay. Make the sanitation necessary.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - Lies and half-truths are those fake news that are increasingly being sold as solid arguments.We are becoming a company that does not want to hear data, numbers.Opponents of the European Union-Canada Free Trade Agreement act in the same way.So let me repeat some truths about CETA.CETA maintains high European standards in the field of food safety.CETA does not allow the use of racial hormones and antibiotics in livestock farming.Imports of beef and pork are quantitatively limited by quotas.CETA does not affect the sowing of genetically modified organisms.CETA will mainly help European small and medium-sized enterprises.The vast majority of customs duties will be abolished.Small and medium-sized enterprises will be significantly more protected in international investment disputes.Also in Slovenia, where I come from: the Canadian Bombardier has an aviation service center in Brnik.Canadian Magna is planning a large investment in Slovenia.CETA will also provide new jobs in Slovenia.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, respect for human dignity is one of the fundamental principles of a democratic state governed by the rule of law. This commandment is all the more important when we think of the elderly, especially those in need of care. Specialist NGOs across Europe help to care for the elderly at home. Their activities receive predictable, planned state support. We have witnessed an incomprehensible and arbitrary decision these days in Romania, where the Ministry of Labor has halved the support of NGOs providing social services without explanation and without prior notice. More than six thousand people could lose their social benefits as support for the organizations that care for them has been cut. As if the wheel of time has turned, 27 years will throw our country back into the past. The government must correct this serious mistake immediately.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to imagine the following situation: you are born somewhere in your homeland, somewhere in Europe, in one country. Your mother and father, your grandparents, will teach you a mother tongue. They live on the land where their parents, grandparents, grandparents, ancestors have always lived. And overnight it will be a different country with a different language. This happened, for example, with the Hungarians of Transcarpathia, who are currently approx. there are two hundred thousand, and what God gives, as Ukraine approaches the European Union, it moves away from the normal human rights values, as far as indigenous national communities are concerned. Now they want to introduce a language law that will effectively ban the use of mother tongues by indigenous national communities, national minorities in your language. I call on them to take very firm action against this language law, because it is incompatible with European Union standards.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, we should realize that the European Union is facing a very serious situation. President Trump is proving to be a new phenomenon that does not provide a sure, predictable partner. The departure of Great Britain is a clear weakening of the European Union. Let us not underestimate the example of Great Britain, which has strengthened the voice of populists in all countries of the European Union. Citizens ask me what our response is as we respond to these challenges. It should be a challenge for us to realize the meaning of the European Union, that if we want to be strong, we must solve real, fundamental problems that individual countries cannot solve at their level. Problems that burn our citizens, such as security, economic growth and the quality of the environment. We will be voting on them this week. These are the counter-terrorism directive, the trade agreement with Canada, the regulation on strengthening external border controls, the reform of the emissions trading. In my opinion, this is a very clear response to the concerns of our citizens, and we should tell them.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, 2016 has been a destructive year and there are more challenges ahead for us in 2017. For those of us who are committed to the European project, these disruptions or challenges should and can provide the opportunity to engage more with other nations and with other economies and to pursue with ambition the completion of EU-negotiated trade agreements. Free trade does not mean a diminution of the EU standards that have been built up over so many years, protecting welfare, health and safety, social rights and entitlements, consumer rights, the right to do business, the right to trade and the need to protect and enhance our environment. Rather, they can be an enhancer, an enabler and a bridge builder. If the EU is to meet the expectations of its citizens it must make full use of the enormous market potential that is there outside its borders and, in so doing, help to shape and influence global standards, standards that we take so much for granted here and yet that have needed such hard work to develop over so many years, standards that will benefit consumers and businesses who will benefit from trade deals, but also encourage dialogue between people and citizens. Bridge building, not building walls, is where we should be now and it is time for Europe to step up to the plate in this area.

name: President. –
text: With apologies and thanking you for your understanding, Mr Negrescu, you have the floor.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Madam President, in the middle of my term as Member of the European Parliament, I am glad to send a new message to all those in Transylvania and Banat who trusted me. I hope I have shown how proud I am to be one of the Romanians who represent this beautiful area. I have spoken many times in the European Parliament to talk about Romania and our area, I have supported the development of a form of representation of local interests in the European capital, I have contributed to numerous promotional actions, including the largest festival of Romanians in Belgium . All these initiatives focused on the importance of our area and, especially, of my soul county, of Alba county. But the most important thing for me was to bring our fighting spirit here in the European Parliament, to fight for our interests and to demand equal treatment for all European citizens. In the future I will organize at the European Parliament a series of conferences and exhibitions for the promotion of Romania, I will look for the centenary of the Union to become an opportunity to increase the profile of our country and Alba Iulia at European level and, especially, I will make sure European funds from pilot projects to reach beneficiaries in Transylvania and Banat.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the item.

name: President. –
text: The sitting tomorrow, Tuesday, 14 February – a very special day, which you will all note – begins at 9.00 in the morning. The agenda has been published and is available on the European Parliament website.
